cards.topic: Understanding Secured Transactions
cards.rawHeader: Secured Transactions 001. Understanding Secured Transactions
cards.front: Understanding Secured Transactions
cards.backPlain: 1. Overview of secured transactions 1.1. Secured transactions involve transactions based on credit and are governed by UCC Article 9. 1.2. One party (the debtor) receives something from another party (the creditor or secured party) without paying immediately. 1.3. To ensure the debtor will pay eventually, the debtor gives the creditor rights to a piece of the debtor's property as collateral (a security interest). 2. Security interest and collateral 2.1. A security interest is a right given to the creditor in the debtor's property. 2.2. Collateral is the property in which the creditor obtains rights. 2.3. The security interest allows the creditor to take or sell the collateral if the debtor fails to fulfill the credit obligation (for example, does not pay the creditor). 2.4. The arrangement is usually memorialized in a security agreement. 3. Attaching and perfecting security interests 3.1. Attachment is the process by which collateral is used to secure the creditor's interest. Effect: Once a security interest attaches, the creditor has a right to take the collateral if the debtor defaults. 3.2. Perfection is the process by which the creditor secures her rights in the collateral as against third parties. When third parties also have an interest in the same collateral, the creditor must perfect her security interest to have priority over those third parties.

cards.easyContent: Under UCC Article 9, a secured transaction uses a security interest in the debtor’s property as collateral for a credit obligation; attachment makes the interest enforceable against the debtor, and perfection protects it against third parties.
cards.mediumContent: Secured transactions under UCC Article 9 involve a debtor receiving value on credit from a creditor or secured party and granting a security interest in collateral—property the creditor can take or sell if the debtor defaults. The arrangement is usually documented in a security agreement. Attachment is the process by which the security interest becomes enforceable against the debtor in the collateral, giving the creditor the right to seize the collateral on default. Perfection is the process that establishes the creditor’s rights in the collateral as against third parties, giving the creditor priority when others also claim an interest in the same collateral.
cards.hardContent: Secured transactions are credit transactions governed by UCC Article 9. The debtor receives value from the creditor or secured party without immediate payment and grants the creditor a security interest in identified collateral. A security interest is the creditor’s right in the debtor’s property, and the collateral is the property subject to that right. If the debtor defaults, the security interest allows the creditor to take or sell the collateral, typically under the terms of a written security agreement. Attachment is the process by which the security interest becomes effective in the collateral as to the debtor, giving the creditor an enforceable right to the collateral upon default. Perfection is a separate process—such as filing or possession—that secures the creditor’s rights in the collateral as against third parties, ensuring priority over competing claimants to the same collateral.
cards.mnemonic: D-C-A-P: Debtor, Collateral, Attachment, Perfection.
cards.clozeLite: In Article 9, a {{c1::security interest}} is the creditor’s right in {{c2::collateral}}; {{c3::attachment}} makes it enforceable against the {{c4::debtor}}, while {{c5::perfection}} protects against {{c6::third parties}}.

cards.subject: Secured Transactions
cards.topic: UCC Article 9 Applicability
cards.rawHeader: Secured Transactions 002. UCC Article 9 Applicability
cards.front: UCC Article 9 Applicability
cards.backPlain: 1. General applicability 1.1. UCC Article 9 applies to any transaction intended to create a security interest in personal property or fixtures. 2. Major exceptions (Article 9 does not apply to these transactions) 2.1. Transactions governed by federal, state, or foreign law that expressly preempt Article 9. 2.2. Most real property transactions involving interests or liens on land (for example, mortgages on real property). 2.3. Assignment of tort claims (except with respect to proceeds and priority in proceeds from tort claims). 2.4. Assignment of claims for wages. 3. Secured transactions versus contracts 3.1. Contract law and UCC Article 2 govern the rules for making and enforcing transactions in goods and services. 3.2. Secured transactions and UCC Article 9 govern how those transactions are protected or secured, not the substantive rules of the underlying exchange.

cards.easyContent: Article 9 governs transactions creating security interests in personal property or fixtures, but not most real property liens, wage assignments, or most tort claim assignments, and it addresses how deals are secured rather than how contracts are formed.
cards.mediumContent: UCC Article 9 applies to any transaction intended to create a security interest in personal property or fixtures. It does not generally apply to transactions governed by other preemptive laws, most real property transactions such as mortgages, assignments of tort claims (other than their proceeds and related priority), or assignments of wage claims. While contract law and UCC Article 2 govern the creation and enforcement of contracts for goods and services, Article 9 governs how those obligations are secured by interests in personal property.
cards.hardContent: UCC Article 9 governs any transaction, regardless of form, that is intended to create a security interest in personal property or fixtures. It is displaced where federal, state, or foreign law specifically governs and preempts Article 9. Article 9 also does not cover most real property transactions involving interests or liens in land, such as mortgages. It excludes assignments of tort claims, except as to their proceeds and disputes over priority in those proceeds, and assignments of claims for wages. Contract law and UCC Article 2 set the rules for forming and enforcing contracts in goods and services, while secured transactions law under Article 9 addresses how those obligations are protected or secured by security interests, rather than the substantive terms of the underlying deal.

cards.topic: Identifying and Classifying Collateral
cards.rawHeader: Secured Transactions 003. Identifying and Classifying Collateral
cards.front: Identifying and Classifying Collateral
cards.backPlain: Article 9 requires that collateral be properly classified, because the type of collateral affects how a security interest is created, perfected, and prioritized. At a high level, collateral falls into two broad groupings: 1. Tangible goods: physical goods, which Article 9 divides into farming goods, consumer goods, inventory, and equipment. 2. Intangible (and quasi‑tangible) property: rights to payment or other property interests, such as instruments, documents, chattel paper, accounts, deposit accounts, and general intangibles. Each subcategory has specific definitions and consequences for attachment, perfection, and priority, so correctly identifying the collateral type is a critical first step in any secured transactions analysis.

Each subcategory has specific definitions and consequences for attachment, perfection, and priority, so correctly identifying the collateral type is a critical first step in any secured transactions analysis.
cards.easyContent: Article 9 collateral must be classified because the rules for attachment, perfection, and priority depend on the type of collateral. Broadly, collateral is either tangible goods (like farming goods, consumer goods, inventory, and equipment) or intangible/quasi‑tangible property (like instruments, documents, chattel paper, accounts, deposit accounts, and general intangibles).
cards.mediumContent: Classifying collateral is the first step in any Article 9 secured transactions problem, because different collateral types follow different rules for creation, perfection, and priority. At a high level, collateral falls into (1) tangible goods—physical items divided into farming goods, consumer goods, inventory, and equipment—and (2) intangible or quasi‑tangible property—rights to money or goods, such as instruments, documents, chattel paper, accounts, deposit accounts, and general intangibles.
cards.hardContent: Collateral classification drives how a security interest is attached, perfected, and prioritized under Article 9. The law divides collateral into two overarching groupings: (1) tangible goods, which are physical goods further divided into farming goods, consumer goods, inventory, and equipment; and (2) intangible (and quasi‑tangible) property, which consists primarily of rights to payment or other personal property interests, including instruments, documents, chattel paper, accounts, deposit accounts, and general intangibles. A correct classification is essential before analyzing filing requirements, control, automatic perfection, and priority contests.

cards.topic: Consignment
cards.rawHeader: Secured Transactions 004. Consignment
cards.front: Consignment
cards.backPlain: 1. Consignments are transactions where an owner of goods (the consignor) such as a manufacturer or wholesaler delivers goods to a merchant (the consignee) for the purpose of sale. 2. Consignment as a security interest: 2.1 A consignment can be treated as a security interest if the inventory the consignee is selling on consignment is difficult to distinguish from inventory the consignee actually owns. 2.2 When a consignee or merchant owns inventory that could be mistaken by a creditor of the consignee for similar inventory that is on consignment (i.e., owned by the consignor), the consignment is considered a security interest and the consignor must comply with Article 9 to give notice to the consignee's creditors. 3. Requirements for Article 9 protection (the consignor must comply with Article 9 to protect her interest in consigned goods against the consignee's creditors if all of the following are met): 3.1 The consigned goods are worth $1,000 or more. 3.2 The consignor did not use the goods for personal, family, or household purposes (for example, consigned used clothes from a consumer are not covered by Article 9). 3.3 The consignee or merchant: 3.3.1 Deals in goods of that kind under a name other than the name of the person making delivery. 3.3.2 Is not an auctioneer. 3.3.3 Is not generally known by its creditors to be substantially engaged in selling goods of others.

cards.easyContent: A consignment is when a consignor delivers goods to a merchant consignee to sell, and in some cases the law treats the consignment as a security interest so the consignor must comply with Article 9 to protect against the consignee’s creditors.
cards.mediumContent: In a consignment, the consignor (owner) delivers goods to a merchant consignee for sale. If consigned inventory is hard to distinguish from the consignee’s own inventory so that creditors could be misled, Article 9 treats the consignment like a security interest. The consignor must then comply with Article 9 (e.g., file) when: the goods are worth $1,000 or more; the consignor did not use them for personal, family, or household purposes; and the consignee deals in goods of that kind under a different name, is not an auctioneer, and is not generally known by its creditors to sell goods of others.
cards.hardContent: A consignment is a transaction where the owner of goods (the consignor, such as a manufacturer or wholesaler) delivers goods to a merchant (the consignee) to sell the goods for the consignor. Article 9 treats a consignment as a security interest when the consignee’s consigned inventory is difficult to distinguish from inventory the consignee owns, so creditors might assume both are the consignee’s property. In that case, to protect its interest against the consignee’s creditors, the consignor must comply with Article 9 (e.g., perfect the interest) if all of the following are satisfied: (1) the consigned goods are worth $1,000 or more; (2) the consignor did not use the goods for personal, family, or household purposes (consumer consignments are excluded); and (3) the consignee or merchant (a) deals in goods of that kind under a name other than the consignor’s name, (b) is not an auctioneer, and (c) is not generally known by its creditors to be substantially engaged in selling goods of others.

cards.subject: Secured Transactions
cards.topic: Creation and Attachment of Security Interests
cards.rawHeader: Secured Transactions 005. Creation and Attachment of Security Interests
cards.front: Creation and Attachment of Security Interests
cards.backPlain: 1. Security interests are created by contract (a security agreement), and security agreements are typically: 1.1 In writing. 1.2 Signed or otherwise authenticated by the debtor. 1.3 Inclusive of a description of the collateral. 1.4 Once a security interest attaches, the obligation is secured, meaning the creditor has a right to take the collateral if the debtor defaults (i.e., fails to pay). 2. Requirements for attachment (three requirements for a security interest to attach): 2.1 Valid security agreement: 2.1.1 An agreement memorializing the security interest. 2.1.2 It may be evidenced by either: 2.1.2.1 An authenticated security agreement, or 2.1.2.2 The creditor's possession or control of the collateral. 2.1.3 Authenticated security agreement: a record authenticated by the debtor that describes the collateral. 2.1.4 Signing, initialing, or similar acts are adequate proof of authentication. 2.1.5 The agreement must reasonably identify the collateral. 2.2 Value: 2.2.1 The secured party (i.e., creditor) must give value to create a security interest. 2.2.2 For example, the creditor loans the debtor money or delivers equipment in exchange for the security interest. 2.2.3 Almost any consideration is sufficient. 2.3 Rights in collateral: 2.3.1 The debtor must have rights in the property offered as collateral. 2.3.2 Ownership or a sufficient possessory interest is usually enough.

cards.easyContent: A security interest is created by a security agreement and attaches when there is an enforceable security agreement, the secured party gives value, and the debtor has rights in the collateral, making the collateral available to the creditor if the debtor defaults.
cards.mediumContent: Article 9 security interests are created by a security agreement, usually a written record authenticated by the debtor that reasonably describes the collateral. A security interest attaches—and thus becomes enforceable against the debtor—when three requirements are met: (1) there is a valid security agreement, either by an authenticated record describing the collateral or by the creditor’s possession or control; (2) the secured party gives value, such as a loan or delivery of goods; and (3) the debtor has rights in the collateral, typically ownership or a sufficient possessory interest.
cards.hardContent: Under Article 9, a security interest arises by contract through a security agreement. The agreement is typically in writing, signed or otherwise authenticated by the debtor, and includes a description that reasonably identifies the collateral. Once the security interest attaches, the obligation is secured and the creditor may look to the collateral if the debtor defaults. Attachment requires three elements: (1) a valid security agreement, either in the form of an authenticated record describing the collateral or the creditor's possession or control of the collateral; (2) value given by the secured party, with almost any consideration being sufficient (e.g., a loan or provision of equipment in exchange for the security interest); and (3) the debtor having rights in the collateral, usually through ownership or another sufficient possessory interest. Only when all three are satisfied does the security interest attach and become enforceable.
cards.mnemonic: Attachment = A-V-R: Agreement, Value, Rights.
cards.clozeLite: A security interest {{c1::attaches}} when there is {{c2::a valid security agreement}}, {{c3::value given by the secured party}}, and {{c4::debtor rights in the collateral}}.

cards.subject: Secured Transactions
cards.topic: Security Agreement Provisions (After Acquired Property, Future Advances, and Specification Clauses)
cards.rawHeader: Secured Transactions 006. Security Agreement Provisions (After Acquired Property, Future Advances, and Specification Clauses)
cards.front: Security Agreement Provisions (After Acquired Property, Future Advances, and Specification Clauses)
cards.backPlain: 1. UCC Article 9 generally gives parties broad discretion to create their own terms regarding security agreements. Common issues include: 1.1 After-acquired property clauses: These extend the security interest to property acquired by the debtor after signing the security agreement. 1.2 Future advances: 1.2.1 Security agreements may contemplate future loans or advances from the creditor to the debtor based on the debtor's present collateral or collateral to be acquired in the future. 1.2.2 In such cases, a new security agreement is not required for each future advance. 1.2.3 For example: L loans $2,000 to D secured by inventory in D's business; the security agreement provides for future advances; D may obtain additional loans in the future from L secured by the same collateral. 1.3 Specification clauses: 1.3.1 Parties may include clauses specifying terms and creating provisions for potential events. 1.3.2 For example: parties may define what constitutes a default or may provide for acceleration of payments upon the happening of a certain event (e.g., one missed payment).
cards.frontPrompt: What are after-acquired property clauses, future advance clauses, and specification clauses in security agreements under Article 9, and what do they allow parties to do?

Common issues include: 1.1 {{c2::After-acquired property clauses}}: These extend the security interest to property {{c3::acquired by the debtor after signing the security agreement}}. 1.2 {{c4::Future advances}}: 1.2.1 Security agreements may contemplate {{c5::future loans or advances}} from the creditor to the debtor based on the debtor's present collateral or collateral to be acquired in the future. 1.2.2 In such cases, a {{c6::new security agreement is not required}} for each future advance. 1.2.3 For example: L loans $2,000 to D secured by inventory in D's business; the security agreement provides for future advances; D may obtain additional loans in the future from L secured by the same collateral. 1.3 {{c7::Specification clauses}}: 1.3.1 Parties may include clauses specifying terms and creating provisions for {{c8::potential events}}. 1.3.2 For example: parties may define what constitutes a {{c9::default}} or may provide for {{c10::acceleration of payments}} upon the happening of a certain event (e.g., one missed payment).
cards.easyContent: Article 9 allows parties to expand a security agreement with clauses that cover after-acquired property, future advances, and specified events like default and acceleration.
cards.mediumContent: Under Article 9, parties can tailor security agreements with (1) after-acquired property clauses, which automatically extend the security interest to property the debtor acquires after the agreement; (2) future advance clauses, which allow future loans or advances to be secured by the same collateral without a new security agreement; and (3) specification clauses, which define key terms and events, such as what counts as a default and when payments may be accelerated.
cards.hardContent: UCC Article 9 gives parties broad contractual freedom in structuring security agreements. Common provisions include: (1) after-acquired property clauses, which extend the security interest to property the debtor acquires after signing, so the creditor’s lien automatically covers new collateral of the described type; (2) future advance clauses, under which the creditor may make additional loans or advances in the future that are secured by the debtor’s present or later-acquired collateral without executing a new security agreement each time; and (3) specification clauses, which allow the parties to spell out key terms and contingencies, such as defining what constitutes a default and authorizing acceleration of payments or other remedies upon specified events, like a missed payment.
cards.mnemonic: A-F-S: After-acquired, Future advances, Specification clauses expand agreements.
cards.clozeLite: Article 9 allows {{c1::after-acquired property clauses}}, {{c2::future advance clauses}}, and {{c3::specification clauses}} to expand a {{c4::security agreement}}.

cards.subject: Secured Transactions
cards.topic: Perfection of Security Interests
cards.rawHeader: Secured Transactions 007. Perfection of Security Interests
cards.front: Perfection of Security Interests
cards.backPlain: 1. In general: A single piece of the debtor's property may serve as collateral for multiple creditors who all have their own security interest. Perfection is relevant to the priority of these interests. Once a security interest is attached it is enforceable, but it must be perfected in order to give its holder (the creditor) priority over other potential security interests in the same collateral. 2. Significance of perfection: A perfected security interest generally has priority over unperfected security interests in the same collateral. Attachment is a prerequisite to perfection. 3. Methods of perfection: 3.1 Filing. 3.2 Taking possession. 3.3 Automatic perfection (e.g., certain purchase-money security interests (PMSIs)). 3.4 Control.
cards.frontPrompt: What is perfection of a security interest under Article 9, why does it matter, and what are the main methods by which a security interest can be perfected?
cards.cloze: 1. In general: A single piece of the debtor's property may serve as collateral for multiple creditors who all have their own {{c1::security interest}}. {{c2::Perfection}} is relevant to the {{c3::priority}} of these interests. Once a security interest is {{c4::attached}} it is enforceable, but it must be perfected in order to give its holder (the creditor) priority over other potential security interests in the same collateral. 2. Significance of perfection: A {{c5::perfected security interest}} generally has priority over {{c6::unperfected security interests}} in the same collateral. {{c7::Attachment is a prerequisite to perfection}}. 3. Methods of perfection: 3.1 {{c8::Filing}}. 3.2 Taking {{c9::possession}}. 3.3 {{c10::Automatic perfection}} (e.g., certain {{c11::purchase-money security interests (PMSIs)}}). 3.4 {{c12::Control}}.
cards.easyContent: Perfection is the step that makes an attached security interest effective against third parties and determines priority among competing secured creditors, usually accomplished by filing, possession, automatic perfection, or control.
cards.mediumContent: After attachment, a security interest must be perfected to establish its priority over other claims in the same collateral. Perfection does not affect enforceability against the debtor but is crucial against third parties. A perfected security interest generally outranks unperfected interests. Attachment is always a prerequisite. The main methods of perfection are filing a financing statement, taking possession of the collateral, automatic perfection in certain cases (especially some PMSIs), and obtaining control over the collateral.
cards.hardContent: Perfection under Article 9 addresses the competition among multiple creditors claiming interests in the same collateral. A security interest becomes enforceable against the debtor upon attachment, but to obtain priority against other secured parties and many third parties, the interest must be perfected. A perfected security interest usually takes precedence over unperfected ones in the same collateral, and perfection presupposes that attachment has already occurred. Perfection can be achieved by: (1) filing a proper financing statement in the correct office; (2) taking possession of the collateral, which itself can both evidence and perfect the interest for certain collateral types; (3) automatic perfection, notably for some purchase-money security interests and other limited categories; and (4) obtaining control over specified types of collateral (such as deposit accounts and investment property).
cards.mnemonic: Perfection gives Priority by F-P-A-C: Filing, Possession, Automatic, Control.
cards.clozeLite: Perfection makes an attached security interest {{c1::effective against third parties}} and generally {{c2::gives priority over unperfected interests}}, usually via {{c3::filing}}, {{c4::possession}}, {{c5::automatic perfection}}, or {{c6::control}}.

cards.subject: Secured Transactions
cards.topic: Methods of Perfecting Security Interests
cards.rawHeader: Secured Transactions 008. Methods of Perfecting Security Interests
cards.front: Methods of Perfecting Security Interests – Overview
cards.backPlain: Primary methods of perfecting a security interest (SI) under Article 9: 1. Filing a financing statement: The most common method; requires correctly naming the debtor, identifying the secured party, adequately describing the collateral, and debtor authorization. 2. Perfection by possession: The secured party may perfect by taking possession of many types of tangible or quasi-tangible collateral (e.g., goods in a pawn-type situation, negotiable documents, and instruments), but not of most intangibles (e.g., accounts or general intangibles). 3. Automatic perfection and PMSIs: In limited situations, perfection occurs automatically upon attachment, particularly for certain purchase-money security interests (PMSIs) where the creditor finances or sells the goods and retains an SI in them. 4. Special rule for motor vehicles: For certificate-of-title vehicles, perfection is generally by notation of the lien on the vehicle’s certificate of title rather than by a standard financing statement filing.
cards.frontPrompt: What are the main methods by which a security interest can be perfected under Article 9, including how filing, possession, automatic perfection (especially PMSIs), and titled motor vehicles fit into the overall scheme?

Special rule for {{c6::motor vehicles}} covered by a certificate of title: generally perfected by {{c7::notation of the lien on the certificate of title}}.
cards.easyContent: A security interest can be perfected mainly by filing, by possession of suitable collateral, by automatic perfection in limited situations like some PMSIs, and for certificate-of-title motor vehicles, by notation of the lien on the title.
cards.mediumContent: Article 9 recognizes several core methods of perfection: (1) filing a financing statement with required information and debtor authorization; (2) perfection by possession of certain types of collateral; (3) automatic perfection in specific situations, especially certain PMSIs when collateral attaches; and (4) a special titling system for motor vehicles, where perfection is usually by noting the lien on the certificate of title rather than a standard filing.
cards.hardContent: Under Article 9, a secured party can perfect a security interest primarily through: (1) filing a financing statement that satisfies formal requirements (correct debtor name, identification of the secured party, adequate collateral description, and debtor authorization); (2) taking possession of appropriate collateral, such as goods, negotiable documents, or instruments, but not of most intangibles like accounts or general intangibles; (3) relying on automatic perfection in limited contexts, most notably certain purchase-money security interests (PMSIs) that perfect upon attachment; and (4) following special certificate-of-title rules for motor vehicles, under which perfection is generally achieved by notation of the lien on the vehicle’s title instead of a financing statement filing.
cards.mnemonic: F-P-A-T: Filing, Possession, Automatic, Title notation.
cards.atomizationNotes: Atomized into four children: (1) filing requirements, (2) perfection by possession and limits, (3) automatic perfection and PMSIs, and (4) certificate-of-title motor vehicles.

cards.subject: Secured Transactions
cards.topic: Automatic Perfection and PMSIs
cards.rawHeader: Secured Transactions 009. Automatic Perfection and PMSIs
cards.front: Automatic Perfection and PMSIs
cards.backPlain: 1. In general: 1.1 In some transactions, security interests are perfected automatically once they have attached; no filing or possession is required. 1.2 Automatic perfection occurs in the following situations. 2. PMSI in consumer goods: 2.1 A purchase-money security interest (PMSI) arises when a creditor sells goods to the debtor and/or advances funds to the debtor to buy goods, reserving a security interest in the goods themselves. 2.2 Example: A sells B a TV on credit. Once the security interest is created and attached (when B receives the goods), A has a PMSI in the TV that is automatically perfected. 2.3 Consumer goods only: automatic perfection only occurs for PMSIs in consumer goods. A PMSI in inventory or equipment must be perfected by filing. 2.4 Limitations: motor vehicles covered by a certificate of title (which require notation on the title) and fixtures (which require a proper fixture filing) are not automatically perfected, even if they are consumer goods. 3. Small assignment of accounts: 3.1 An SI is automatically perfected when accounts or payment intangibles are assigned, and 3.2 The assignment does not transfer a significant portion of the assignor’s outstanding accounts or payment intangibles. 4. Sale of payment intangibles or promissory notes: 4.1 A security interest in a sale of payment intangibles or promissory notes is automatically perfected upon attachment.
cards.frontPrompt: When does Article 9 provide for automatic perfection of a security interest, particularly for PMSIs in consumer goods, small assignments of accounts, and sales of payment intangibles or promissory notes?
cards.cloze: 1. In general: 1.1 In some transactions, {{c1::security interests are perfected automatically once they have attached}}; no filing or possession is required. 1.2 Automatic perfection occurs in the following situations. 2. {{c2::PMSI in consumer goods}}: 2.1 A {{c3::purchase-money security interest (PMSI)}} arises when a creditor sells goods to the debtor and/or advances funds to the debtor to buy goods, reserving a security interest in the goods themselves. 2.2 Example: A sells B a TV on credit. Once the security interest is created and {{c4::attached}} (when B receives the goods), A has a PMSI in the TV that is {{c5::automatically perfected}}. 2.3 {{c6::Consumer goods only}}: automatic perfection only occurs for PMSIs in consumer goods. A PMSI in {{c7::inventory or equipment}} must be perfected by filing. 2.4 Limitations: {{c8::motor vehicles}} covered by a certificate of title (which require {{c9::notation on the title}}) and {{c10::fixtures}} (which require a proper {{c11::fixture filing}}) are not automatically perfected, even if they are consumer goods. 3. {{c12::Small assignment of accounts}}: 3.1 An SI is automatically perfected when {{c13::accounts or payment intangibles are assigned}}, and 3.2 The assignment does not transfer a {{c14::significant portion of the assignor’s outstanding accounts or payment intangibles}}. 4. {{c15::Sale of payment intangibles or promissory notes}}: 4.1 A security interest in a sale of payment intangibles or promissory notes is {{c16::automatically perfected upon attachment}}.
cards.easyContent: Automatic perfection generally occurs for PMSIs in consumer goods, small assignments of accounts or payment intangibles, and sales of payment intangibles or promissory notes, without the need for filing or possession.
cards.mediumContent: Article 9 provides automatic perfection when: (1) a PMSI in consumer goods attaches—this perfects automatically, but does not apply to PMSIs in inventory or equipment, and motor vehicles and fixtures still require title notation or fixture filing; (2) there is a small assignment of accounts or payment intangibles, so long as the assignment does not transfer a significant portion of the assignor’s outstanding accounts or intangibles; and (3) upon attachment of a security interest in the sale of payment intangibles or promissory notes.
cards.hardContent: In some transactions, security interests are perfected automatically upon attachment. The main case is a purchase-money security interest in consumer goods: a PMSI arises when a creditor sells goods to the debtor or advances funds for the purchase and retains an SI in those goods; once the SI attaches (e.g., when the debtor receives the goods), it is automatically perfected without filing. This automatic rule applies only to consumer goods; PMSIs in inventory or equipment require filing to perfect, and even for consumer goods, motor vehicles covered by a certificate of title and fixtures must be perfected by notation on the title or a proper fixture filing, respectively. Automatic perfection also applies to small assignments of accounts or payment intangibles, provided the assignment does not transfer a significant portion of the assignor’s outstanding accounts or payment intangibles. Finally, a security interest in the sale of payment intangibles or promissory notes is automatically perfected upon attachment.
cards.mnemonic: Automatic CAP: Consumer-goods PMSI, small Assignments, Payment intangibles/notes sales.
cards.clozeLite: Article 9 gives automatic perfection for {{c1::PMSIs in consumer goods}} (not inventory/equipment), {{c2::small assignments of accounts or payment intangibles}}, and {{c3::sales of payment intangibles or promissory notes}}.

cards.subject: Secured Transactions
cards.topic: Temporary Perfection of Proceeds
cards.rawHeader: Secured Transactions 010. Temporary Perfection of Proceeds
cards.front: Temporary Perfection of Proceeds
cards.backPlain: 1. In general: 1.1 A security interest in proceeds from original collateral is perfected automatically for 20 days from the debtor’s receipt of the proceeds, but may become unperfected on the 21st day. 1.2 This arises where the debtor sells or otherwise disposes of property that was used as collateral. 1.3 Article 9 gives the creditor an automatic security interest in identifiable proceeds from the sale or disposition of collateral. 2. Identifiable proceeds: 2.1 A security interest in proceeds from collateral is automatically perfected for 20 days from the debtor’s receipt of the proceeds. 2.2 Example: A TV store takes a loan and puts its TV inventory up as collateral. The store can continue selling TVs, but the creditor has an automatically perfected SI in the store’s identifiable TV proceeds for 20 days after the proceeds are received. 3. Continuing perfection beyond 20 days: 3.1 A perfected security interest in proceeds becomes unperfected on the 21st day after the security interest attaches to the proceeds unless: 3.1.1 A filed financing statement covers the original collateral; 3.1.2 The proceeds are collateral in which a security interest may be perfected by filing in the same office where the financing statement for the original collateral has been filed; and 3.1.3 The proceeds are not acquired with cash proceeds (i.e., they are non-cash proceeds that remain traceable from the original collateral and filing office).
cards.frontPrompt: How does Article 9 treat temporary perfection of a security interest in proceeds, including the 20-day automatic perfection period and the conditions for maintaining perfection beyond 20 days?
cards.cloze: 1. In general: 1.1 A security interest in {{c1::proceeds}} from original collateral is perfected {{c2::automatically for 20 days}} from the debtor’s receipt of the proceeds, but may become {{c3::unperfected on the 21st day}}. 1.2 This arises where the debtor {{c4::sells or otherwise disposes of property that was used as collateral}}. 1.3 Article 9 gives the creditor an automatic security interest in {{c5::identifiable proceeds}} from the sale or disposition of collateral. 2. {{c6::Identifiable proceeds}}: 2.1 A security interest in proceeds from collateral is automatically perfected for {{c7::20 days}} from the debtor’s receipt of the proceeds. 2.2 Example: A TV store takes a loan and puts its TV inventory up as collateral. The store can continue selling TVs, but the creditor has an automatically perfected SI in the store’s identifiable TV proceeds for 20 days after the proceeds are received. 3. {{c8::Continuing perfection beyond 20 days}}: 3.1 A perfected security interest in proceeds becomes unperfected on the 21st day after the security interest attaches to the proceeds unless: 3.1.1 A filed {{c9::financing statement}} covers the {{c10::original collateral}}; 3.1.2 The proceeds are collateral in which a security interest may be perfected by {{c11::filing in the same office}} where the financing statement for the original collateral has been filed; and 3.1.3 The proceeds are {{c12::not acquired with cash proceeds}} (i.e., they are non-cash proceeds that remain traceable from the original collateral and filing office).
cards.easyContent: A perfected security interest automatically continues in identifiable proceeds of collateral for 20 days after the debtor receives the proceeds, but will lapse on day 21 unless specific conditions for continuing perfection are met.
cards.mediumContent: When collateral is sold or disposed of, Article 9 grants the secured party an automatically perfected security interest in identifiable proceeds for 20 days after the debtor receives the proceeds. After 20 days, the security interest becomes unperfected unless: (1) a filed financing statement covers the original collateral; (2) the proceeds are collateral that can be perfected by filing in the same office as the original financing statement; and (3) the proceeds are not acquired with cash proceeds (i.e., they remain traceable non-cash proceeds).
cards.hardContent: Article 9 provides that when a debtor sells or otherwise disposes of collateral, the secured party has an automatically perfected security interest in the identifiable proceeds of that collateral for 20 days from the debtor’s receipt of the proceeds. During this 20-day period, no further action is needed. After 20 days, however, the security interest in proceeds becomes unperfected on day 21 unless three conditions are met: (1) a filed financing statement already covers the original collateral; (2) the proceeds are collateral of a type that may be perfected by filing in the same office where the original financing statement is on file; and (3) the proceeds are not acquired with cash proceeds, meaning they are non-cash proceeds that remain identifiable and traceable through the same filing system.
cards.mnemonic: PRO20: Proceeds auto-perfect 20 days, then need filing, same office, non-cash.
cards.clozeLite: Article 9 gives {{c1::automatic perfection in identifiable proceeds}} for {{c2::20 days}}; after that, it stays perfected only if {{c3::financing statement covers original collateral}}, {{c4::same-office filing}}, and {{c5::non-cash, traceable proceeds}}.

cards.subject: Secured Transactions
cards.topic: Priority of Security Interests
cards.rawHeader: Secured Transactions 011. Priority of Security Interests
cards.front: Priority of Security Interests
cards.backPlain: 1. In general: 1.1 Almost any Secured Transactions essay will involve issues of priority. Always note the type of collateral involved (goods, inventory, livestock, equipment, etc.) and the type of parties involved (secured party vs. secured party, secured party vs. unsecured party, secured party vs. lien creditor, etc.). 1.2 Priority between parties is generally governed by the following rules. 2. Attached vs. unattached/unsecured interests: 2.1 An attached security interest prevails over a mere unsecured or unattached interest. 2.2 Beware scenarios where someone has signed a security agreement but the secured party has not yet given value or the debtor has no rights in the collateral—attachment has not yet occurred, so priority may fail. 3. Perfected vs. unperfected security interests: 3.1 A perfected security interest prevails over an unperfected security interest. 3.2 This rule applies even if the perfected party took its interest with knowledge of an earlier unperfected interest. 4. Perfected vs. perfected security interests: 4.1 As between conflicting perfected security interests, the "first to file or perfect" rule applies: the party that first either files a financing statement or otherwise perfects its interest has priority. 4.2 When there are conflicting perfected SIs, priority goes to the party that first filed or perfected (usually the first to file). 4.3 Where collateral is not subject to filing (or cannot be perfected by filing), the first to perfect obtains priority. 4.4 Knowledge of a prior unperfected SI does not prevent a prospective secured party from filing first to obtain priority under the first-to-file-or-perfect rule.
cards.frontPrompt: What are the basic Article 9 priority rules governing attached vs. unsecured interests, perfected vs. unperfected interests, and conflicts between perfected security interests?
cards.cloze: 1. In general: 1.1 Almost any Secured Transactions essay will involve issues of {{c1::priority}}. Always note the type of {{c2::collateral}} involved (goods, inventory, livestock, equipment, etc.) and the type of {{c3::parties}} involved (secured party vs. secured party, secured party vs. unsecured party, secured party vs. lien creditor, etc.). 1.2 Priority between parties is generally governed by the following rules. 2. {{c4::Attached vs. unattached/unsecured interests}}: 2.1 An {{c5::attached security interest}} prevails over a mere {{c6::unsecured or unattached interest}}. 2.2 Beware scenarios where someone has signed a {{c7::security agreement}} but the secured party has not yet given {{c8::value}} or the debtor has no {{c9::rights in the collateral}}—attachment has not yet occurred, so priority may fail. 3. {{c10::Perfected vs. unperfected}} security interests: 3.1 A {{c11::perfected security interest}} prevails over an {{c12::unperfected security interest}}. 3.2 This rule applies even if the perfected party took its interest with {{c13::knowledge of an earlier unperfected interest}}. 4. {{c14::Perfected vs. perfected}} security interests: 4.1 As between conflicting perfected security interests, the {{c15::"first to file or perfect"}} rule applies: the party that first either files a financing statement or otherwise perfects its interest has priority. 4.2 When there are conflicting perfected SIs, priority goes to the party that first filed or perfected (usually the first to file). 4.3 Where collateral is not subject to filing (or cannot be perfected by filing), the {{c16::first to perfect}} obtains priority. 4.4 {{c17::Knowledge of a prior unperfected SI}} does not prevent a prospective secured party from filing first to obtain priority under the {{c18::first-to-file-or-perfect rule}}.
cards.easyContent: Priority rules generally favor: (1) attached interests over unsecured or unattached claims; (2) perfected security interests over unperfected ones; and (3) between perfected interests, the party that first filed or perfected.
cards.mediumContent: Article 9 priority rules work in layers. First, an attached security interest beats an unsecured or unattached interest, so the secured party must have given value and the debtor must have rights in the collateral. Second, a perfected security interest always prevails over an unperfected one, even if the perfected party knew of the earlier unperfected interest. Third, when two security interests are both perfected, priority usually follows a "first to file or perfect" rule—whoever first filed a financing statement or otherwise perfected wins; where filing is not available, the first to actually perfect takes priority.
cards.hardContent: Priority analysis under Article 9 requires identifying the collateral type and parties. An attached security interest prevails over an unsecured or merely inchoate interest, but attachment requires a security agreement, value, and the debtor’s rights in the collateral—if any of these are missing, the would-be secured party has no priority. Between security interests, perfection is critical: a perfected security interest defeats an unperfected one even if the perfected creditor had knowledge of the earlier unperfected interest. When both interests are perfected, the default rule is first-to-file-or-perfect: the creditor that first files a financing statement covering the collateral or otherwise perfects (whichever occurs first) takes priority. For collateral not subject to filing, the first creditor to actually perfect has priority. Knowledge of prior unperfected security interests does not bar a later creditor from filing first and thereby gaining priority under the first-to-file-or-perfect rule.
cards.mnemonic: Priority ladder A-P-FF: Attached, Perfected, First to File or Perfect.
cards.clozeLite: Article 9 priority: {{c1::attached}} beats {{c2::unsecured}}, {{c3::perfected}} beats {{c4::unperfected}}, and among perfected, {{c5::first to file or perfect}} wins.

cards.subject: Secured Transactions
cards.topic: Priority in PMSIs
cards.rawHeader: Secured Transactions 012. Priority in PMSIs
cards.front: Priority in PMSIs
cards.backPlain: 1. In general: 1.1 Purchase-money security interests (PMSIs) are "superpriority" interests, meaning they can be superior to prior perfected security interests in the same goods, if statutory conditions are met. 2. PMSI in inventory: 2.1 A PMSI in inventory has priority over other security interests in the same inventory and its proceeds (including instruments, chattel paper, and identifiable cash proceeds) if: 2.1.1 The PMSI is perfected when the debtor takes possession of the inventory; and 2.1.2 Other parties who have filed security interests in the inventory receive authenticated notification of the PMSI before the debtor takes possession of the inventory; and 2.1.3 The notification states that a PMSI will be taken in the debtor’s inventory and describes the kind or type of inventory. 3. PMSI in goods other than inventory or livestock (e.g., equipment or consumer goods): 3.1 A PMSI in goods (other than inventory or livestock) has priority over other security interests in the same goods and their proceeds if the PMSI is perfected before or within 20 days after the debtor receives possession of the collateral; and 3.2 There is no requirement that the secured party notify other security interest holders. 4. Conflicting PMSIs: 4.1 Where there are multiple PMSIs in the same collateral, priority goes to the secured party who has a PMSI as the seller of the collateral (as opposed to a mere lender); or 4.2 Otherwise, priority goes to the first secured party to file or perfect. 4.3 Example: A takes a $300 loan from a bank to buy a $500 TV, giving the bank an SI in the TV. A then signs a $200 credit agreement with the TV store to complete the purchase, and the store retains an SI in the TV. The store, as the seller of the collateral, has priority over the bank as the lender.
cards.frontPrompt: How do PMSIs obtain superpriority over other security interests in inventory, in non-inventory goods, and when there are conflicting PMSIs in the same collateral?
cards.cloze: 1. In general: 1.1 {{c1::Purchase-money security interests (PMSIs)}} are {{c2::"superpriority"}} interests, meaning they can be superior to prior perfected security interests in the same goods, if statutory conditions are met. 2. {{c3::PMSI in inventory}}: 2.1 A PMSI in inventory has priority over other security interests in the same inventory and its {{c4::proceeds}} (including instruments, chattel paper, and identifiable cash proceeds) if: 2.1.1 The PMSI is {{c5::perfected when the debtor takes possession}} of the inventory; and 2.1.2 Other parties who have filed security interests in the inventory receive {{c6::authenticated notification}} of the PMSI {{c7::before the debtor takes possession}} of the inventory; and 2.1.3 The notification states that a PMSI will be taken in the debtor’s inventory and {{c8::describes the kind or type of inventory}}. 3. {{c9::PMSI in goods other than inventory or livestock}} (e.g., equipment or consumer goods): 3.1 A PMSI in such goods has priority over other security interests in the same goods and their proceeds if the PMSI is perfected {{c10::before or within 20 days after}} the debtor receives possession of the collateral; and 3.2 There is {{c11::no requirement to notify}} other security interest holders. 4. {{c12::Conflicting PMSIs}}: 4.1 Where there are multiple PMSIs in the same collateral, priority goes to the secured party who has a PMSI as the {{c13::seller of the collateral}} (as opposed to a mere lender); or 4.2 Otherwise, priority goes to the {{c14::first secured party to file or perfect}}. 4.3 Example: A takes a $300 loan from a bank to buy a $500 TV, giving the bank an SI in the TV. A then signs a $200 credit agreement with the TV store to complete the purchase, and the store retains an SI in the TV. The store, as the seller of the collateral, has priority over the bank as the lender.
cards.easyContent: PMSIs can leapfrog earlier security interests. A PMSI in inventory must be perfected when the debtor gets the inventory and prior filers must be notified; a PMSI in non-inventory goods must be perfected before or within 20 days after the debtor receives the goods; and between competing PMSIs, the seller PMSI wins, otherwise first to file or perfect.
cards.mediumContent: PMSIs enjoy superpriority over earlier security interests if strict conditions are met. For inventory, the PMSI must be perfected when the debtor takes possession, and any secured parties with filed interests in that inventory must receive authenticated notice before possession, stating that a PMSI will be taken and describing the inventory type. For goods other than inventory or livestock (like equipment or consumer goods), the PMSI has priority if it is perfected before or within 20 days after the debtor receives the collateral, and no notice to other secured parties is required. When two PMSIs conflict in the same collateral, the PMSI of the seller of the collateral prevails; if both are lenders or this rule does not decide it, priority goes to the first PMSI to file or perfect.
cards.hardContent: Purchase-money security interests (PMSIs) are superpriority interests that can defeat earlier perfected security interests in the same goods. A PMSI in inventory has priority over other interests in that inventory and its proceeds (including instruments, chattel paper, and identifiable cash proceeds) if: (1) the PMSI is perfected at the time the debtor takes possession of the inventory; (2) other creditors who have filed security interests in that inventory receive authenticated notification of the PMSI before the debtor takes possession; and (3) the notice states that a PMSI will be taken in the debtor’s inventory and describes the kind or type of inventory. For goods other than inventory or livestock (e.g., equipment or consumer goods), a PMSI has priority if it is perfected before or within 20 days after the debtor receives possession of the collateral; no notice to other secured parties is required. If multiple PMSIs exist in the same collateral, priority goes first to the PMSI of the seller of the collateral; if that does not resolve the conflict, the first PMSI to file or perfect has priority.
cards.mnemonic: I-N-20-S/F: Inventory-Notice; Non-inventory-20 days; Seller then First.
cards.clozeLite: A PMSI in {{c1::inventory}} needs {{c2::perfection when debtor takes possession}} plus {{c3::prior authenticated notice}}; in {{c4::non-inventory goods}}, it must be perfected {{c5::before or within 20 days}} of debtor’s receipt.

cards.subject: Secured Transactions
cards.topic: Priority in Proceeds
cards.rawHeader: Secured Transactions 013. Priority in Proceeds
cards.front: Priority in Proceeds
cards.backPlain: 1. General rule for proceeds priority 1.1 A perfected security interest in proceeds generally has the same date of priority as the security interest in the original collateral that generated the proceeds. 2. Effect of type of original collateral 2.1 Filing collateral: The secured party would normally achieve priority by filing a financing statement (for example, goods, accounts, and general intangibles). 2.2 Non-filing collateral: The secured party would normally achieve priority by possession or control, not filing (for example, cash, chattel paper, negotiable documents, and instruments).
cards.frontPrompt: How is priority in proceeds determined, and how do filing collateral and non-filing collateral affect that priority?
cards.cloze: 1. {{c1::General rule for proceeds priority}} 1.1 A {{c2::perfected security interest in proceeds}} generally has the {{c3::same date of priority}} as the security interest in the {{c4::original collateral}} that generated the proceeds. 2. {{c5::Effect of type of original collateral}} 2.1 {{c6::Filing collateral}}: The secured party would normally achieve priority by {{c7::filing a financing statement}} (for example, {{c8::goods, accounts, and general intangibles}}). 2.2 {{c9::Non-filing collateral}}: The secured party would normally achieve priority by {{c10::possession or control, not filing}} (for example, {{c11::cash, chattel paper, negotiable documents, and instruments}}).
cards.easyContent: A perfected security interest in proceeds generally has the same priority date as the security interest in the original collateral. Priority usually depends on whether the original collateral was the kind normally perfected by filing or by possession/control.
cards.mediumContent: A perfected security interest in proceeds takes the same priority date as the security interest in the original collateral. If the original collateral is filing collateral (like goods, accounts, or general intangibles), priority is normally achieved by filing. If the original collateral is non-filing collateral (like cash, chattel paper, negotiable documents, or instruments), priority is normally achieved by possession or control, not filing.
cards.hardContent: A perfected security interest in proceeds generally has the same date of priority as the security interest in the original collateral that generated the proceeds. Priority in proceeds often turns on the type of original collateral: (1) for filing collateral—such as goods, accounts, and general intangibles—the secured party normally achieves priority by filing a financing statement; and (2) for non-filing collateral—such as cash, chattel paper, negotiable documents, and instruments—the secured party normally achieves priority by possession or control, rather than by filing.
cards.mnemonic: Proceeds piggyback: same date, follow filing vs. control.

cards.subject: Secured Transactions
cards.topic: Security Interests in Fixtures, Accessions, and Crops
cards.rawHeader: Secured Transactions 014. Security Interests in Fixtures, Accessions, and Crops
cards.front: Security Interests in Fixtures, Accessions, and Crops
cards.backPlain: UCC Article 9 governs security interests in certain goods related to real property or other goods. 1. Fixtures Fixtures are goods attached to real property such that an interest in them arises under real property law. Priority in fixtures generally follows a first‑to‑file‑or‑record rule, with a special PMSI fixture‑filing exception that can allow the PMSI secured party to defeat a prior real property interest. 2. Accessions Accessions are goods that become physically united with other goods but do not lose their separate identity. A security interest in collateral continues even after it becomes an accession. 3. Crops A perfected security interest in crops has priority over an interest in the land on which the crops are grown, regardless of the relative time of filing or perfection.
cards.frontPrompt: How does Article 9 treat security interests in fixtures, accessions, and crops, at a high level, including the key priority rules and the PMSI exception for fixtures?
cards.cloze: UCC Article 9 governs security interests in certain goods related to real property or other goods. 1. {{c1::Fixtures}} – goods attached to real property; priority is generally {{c2::first to file or record}}, with a {{c3::PMSI fixture‑filing exception}} that can defeat a prior real property interest. 2. {{c4::Accessions}} – goods physically united with other goods that {{c5::do not lose their identity}}; a {{c6::security interest continues}} after the collateral becomes an accession. 3. {{c7::Crops}} – a {{c8::perfected security interest in crops}} has priority over {{c9::interests in the land}} where they are grown, {{c10::regardless of time of filing or perfection}}.
cards.easyContent: Article 9 covers fixtures, accessions, and crops. Fixtures generally follow a first‑to‑file‑or‑record priority rule, with a PMSI fixture‑filing exception that can beat an earlier real property interest. Accessions keep their identity when added to other goods, and the security interest continues. A perfected security interest in crops beats land interests regardless of filing time.
cards.mediumContent: For fixtures, Article 9 treats them as goods attached to real property and uses a first‑to‑file‑or‑record priority regime, with a PMSI exception if the PMSI creditor makes a timely fixture filing. Accessions are goods that retain their identity when physically united with other goods, and any Article 9 security interest in them continues even after they become accessions. For crops, a perfected security interest in the crops has priority over any interest in the land on which the crops are grown, regardless of which was filed or perfected first.
cards.hardContent: Article 9 governs security interests in (1) fixtures, (2) accessions, and (3) crops, each with distinctive priority rules. Fixtures are goods attached to real property, generally subject to a first‑to‑file‑or‑record rule as between a security interest in the fixtures and a real property interest, but a properly perfected PMSI with a timely fixture filing can defeat even a prior real property interest. Accessions are items that become physically united with other goods but retain their separate identity, and a security interest in the collateral continues after it becomes an accession. For crops, a perfected security interest in the crops primes an interest in the underlying land regardless of the order of filing or perfection.

cards.subject: Secured Transactions
cards.topic: Priority of Buyers v. Third Party Creditors
cards.rawHeader: Secured Transactions 015. Priority of Buyers v. Third Party Creditors
cards.front: Priority of Buyers v. Third Party Creditors
cards.backPlain: Overview: Buyers can sometimes take goods free of a secured creditor’s interest, especially when they lack knowledge that the sale violates the secured party’s rights. Priority issues most often arise in three contexts: 1. Consumer-to-consumer ("garage sale") rule for PMSIs in consumer goods: A second consumer buyer without knowledge, who pays value before any financing statement is filed, can take free of a PMSI in consumer goods.

cards.topic: Secured Parties v. Judicial Lien Creditors
cards.rawHeader: Secured Transactions 016. Secured Parties v. Judicial Lien Creditors
cards.front: Secured Parties v. Judicial Lien Creditors
cards.backPlain: 1. Judicial lien creditors 1.1 Judicial lien creditors (JLCs) are those who acquire a lien on collateral through judicial attachment, levy, or similar judicial process. 2. Perfected secured party vs. JLC 2.1 A prior perfected security interest prevails over a JLC. 2.2 A JLC prevails only if the creditor becomes a JLC before a secured party files or perfects. 2.3 Future advances: If a secured party makes future advances to the debtor, the secured party has priority for those future advances if: 2.3.1 The future advance was made before, or within 45 days after, the lien arose; or 2.3.2 The future advance was made without knowledge of the lien. 3. Unperfected secured party vs. JLC 3.1 A JLC prevails over an unperfected secured party. 3.2 PMSI grace period exception: A secured party who attaches a PMSI in collateral before the JLC acquires an interest in the collateral has priority if the secured party files within 20 days after the debtor receives the collateral.
cards.frontPrompt: How does priority work between secured parties and judicial lien creditors, including the rules for future advances and the PMSI grace period?

cards.easyContent: A perfected secured party generally beats a judicial lien creditor, while a judicial lien creditor beats an unperfected secured party. Future advances and PMSI grace period rules can preserve the secured party’s priority if timely and without knowledge of the lien.
cards.mediumContent: Judicial lien creditors (JLCs) obtain liens by judicial attachment, levy, or similar processes. A prior perfected secured party prevails over a JLC; a JLC prevails only if it becomes a JLC before the secured party files or perfects. For future advances, the secured party has priority if the advance is made before or within 45 days after the lien arises, or is made without knowledge of the lien. As to unperfected secured parties, a JLC prevails, except that a secured party with a PMSI who attaches before the JLC’s interest arises will have priority if it files within 20 days after the debtor receives the collateral.
cards.hardContent: Judicial lien creditors (JLCs) are creditors who obtain liens on collateral through judicial attachment, levy, or similar judicial processes. When a perfected secured party competes with a JLC, a prior perfected security interest prevails; a JLC prevails only if it becomes a JLC before the secured party files or otherwise perfects. For future advances, the secured party’s priority extends to advances made before, or within 45 days after, the lien arises, or to advances made later without knowledge of the lien. When the secured party is unperfected, a JLC generally prevails. However, under the PMSI grace period, a secured party that attaches a PMSI in the collateral before the JLC acquires its interest has priority if the secured party files within 20 days after the debtor receives the collateral.

cards.subject: Secured Transactions
cards.topic: Default and Right to Repossess or Collect
cards.rawHeader: Secured Transactions 017. Default and Right to Repossess or Collect
cards.front: Default and Right to Repossess or Collect
cards.backPlain: 1. Default and self-help repossession 1.1 Default is generally defined in the security agreement, not by Article 9. 1.2 Upon default, a secured party may take possession of collateral without judicial process (self-help), or may collect on non-goods via authenticated notification, so long as no breach of the peace occurs. 1.3 Reclaiming possession through self-help is allowed only if it does not involve a breach of the peace. 2. Breach of the peace 2.1 A breach of the peace occurs when repossession is made over the debtor's protest. 2.2 Violence, threats of violence, or breaking and entering will likely constitute a breach of the peace. 2.3 Simple trespass in order to repossess property is generally permissible. 2.4 Example: It is permissible to unlock and hot-wire a car used as collateral if the car is sitting in a driveway. 3. Collection rights for non-goods collateral 3.1 When the collateral is non-goods (for example, accounts or instruments), upon default the secured party can notify the person owing the debtor (the account debtor). 3.2 The secured party must send authenticated notification to the account debtor stating that the amount due has been assigned and that payment must be made to the secured party. 3.3 Upon such notification, the account debtor can discharge his obligation only by paying the secured party. 3.4 Example: A loans B $10,000, for which A receives a promissory note. A takes out a loan from C for $5,000 using B's promissory note as collateral. A defaults on C's loan. C may notify B of A's default and require that B pay C on the promissory note.
cards.frontPrompt: After default, what rights does a secured party have to repossess collateral or collect on non-goods, and what constitutes a breach of the peace?

A takes out a loan from C for $5,000 using B's promissory note as collateral. A defaults on C's loan. C may notify B of A's default and require that B pay C on the promissory note.
cards.easyContent: On default, a secured party may repossess collateral by self-help if it avoids a breach of the peace, or may collect directly from account debtors on non-goods after authenticated notice. Breach of the peace includes debtor protests, violence, or breaking and entering.
cards.mediumContent: Default is generally defined by the security agreement, not Article 9. After default, a secured party may repossess collateral without judicial process (self-help) or collect on non-goods collateral if it sends authenticated notice, but any self-help repossession must not involve a breach of the peace. A breach of the peace includes repossession over the debtor’s protest, or involving violence, threats, or breaking and entering, although simple trespass (like entering a driveway to tow a car) is usually permissible. For non-goods like accounts or instruments, the secured party may notify the account debtor that the obligation has been assigned and payment must be made to the secured party, and after notice the account debtor can discharge only by paying the secured party.
cards.hardContent: Default is determined by the parties’ security agreement, not by Article 9 itself. Upon default, a secured party may repossess collateral via self-help (without judicial process) or may collect directly on non-goods collateral through authenticated notification, but any self-help repossession must avoid a breach of the peace. A breach of the peace occurs when repossession is made over the debtor’s protest or involves violence, threats, or breaking and entering; simple trespass, such as unlocking and hot-wiring a car sitting in a driveway, is generally allowed. For non-goods collateral such as accounts or instruments, the secured party may notify the account debtor that the debt has been assigned and that payment must be made to the secured party; once properly notified, the account debtor can discharge the obligation only by paying the secured party.

cards.subject: Secured Transactions
cards.topic: Post Default Disposition of Collateral by Secured Party
cards.rawHeader: Secured Transactions 018. Post Default Disposition of Collateral by Secured Party
cards.front: Post Default Disposition of Collateral by Secured Party
cards.backPlain: After default, Article 9 governs what a secured party may do with collateral. 1. Disposition & notice (overview) - A secured party may dispose of collateral (e.g., by sale, lease, or other disposition) after default, but the disposition must be conducted in a commercially reasonable manner and preceded by reasonable authenticated notice to the debtor. - A proper sale discharges the foreclosing security interest and all subordinate interests, and the purchaser generally takes the debtor’s rights in the collateral. 2. Surplus & deficiency (overview) - If the disposition proceeds exceed the secured obligation, the secured party must pay any surplus to the debtor. - If the proceeds are less than the obligation, the debtor is generally liable for a deficiency. - Exception: For collateral consisting of accounts, chattel paper, payment intangibles, or promissory notes, neither party is liable for a surplus or deficiency. 3. Right to redeem (overview) - Until the collateral is sold or the debt is discharged by retention (strict foreclosure), the debtor or another secured party may redeem by paying off the remaining obligation plus reasonable repossession expenses.
cards.frontPrompt: After default under Article 9, what are the main rules governing disposition of collateral, surplus/deficiency, and redemption?
cards.cloze: After default, Article 9 governs what a {{c1::secured party}} may do with {{c2::collateral}}. 1. {{c3::Disposition & notice}} (overview) - A secured party may {{c4::dispose of collateral}} (e.g., by sale, lease, or other disposition) after default, but the disposition must be conducted in a {{c5::commercially reasonable}} manner and preceded by {{c6::reasonable authenticated notice}} to the debtor. - A proper sale {{c7::discharges the foreclosing security interest}} and all {{c8::subordinate interests}}, and the purchaser generally takes the {{c9::debtor’s rights in the collateral}}. 2. {{c10::Surplus & deficiency}} (overview) - If proceeds exceed the obligation, the secured party must pay any {{c11::surplus}} to the debtor. - If proceeds are less than the obligation, the debtor is generally liable for a {{c12::deficiency}}. - {{c13::Exception}}: For collateral consisting of {{c14::accounts, chattel paper, payment intangibles, or promissory notes}}, neither party is liable for a surplus or deficiency. 3. {{c15::Right to redeem}} (overview) - Until the collateral is sold or the debt is discharged by {{c16::strict foreclosure}}, the debtor or another secured party may {{c17::redeem}} by paying the {{c18::remaining obligation plus reasonable repossession expenses}}.
cards.easyContent: After default, a secured party can dispose of collateral in a commercially reasonable way with reasonable authenticated notice, a sale can create a surplus (owed to the debtor) or a deficiency (owed by the debtor) subject to a limited collateral exception, and the debtor has a right to redeem until sale or strict foreclosure.
cards.mediumContent: Article 9 allows a secured party, after default, to dispose of collateral (by sale, lease, or other disposition) so long as the disposition is commercially reasonable and preceded by reasonable authenticated notice to the debtor. A proper sale cuts off the foreclosing and subordinate security interests, and the buyer takes the debtor’s rights in the collateral. If sale proceeds exceed the debt, the secured party must remit the surplus to the debtor; if the proceeds fall short, the debtor is generally liable for a deficiency, unless the collateral consists of accounts, chattel paper, payment intangibles, or promissory notes, in which case neither party is liable for surplus or deficiency. Until the collateral is sold or the debt is discharged by retention (strict foreclosure), the debtor or another secured party may redeem by paying the full remaining obligation plus reasonable repossession expenses.
cards.hardContent: Upon default, Article 9 authorizes a secured party to dispose of collateral—by sale, lease, or other commercially reasonable disposition—after providing the debtor with an authenticated notice sent within a reasonable time before the sale or other disposition. A compliant sale discharges the security interest under which the sale is made and all subordinate security interests and liens, and the purchaser takes the debtor’s rights in the collateral. If the disposition proceeds exceed the amount of the secured obligation, the secured party must remit any surplus to the debtor; if the proceeds are less than the obligation, the debtor remains liable for the resulting deficiency. However, for underlying transactions involving accounts, chattel paper, payment intangibles, or promissory notes, neither party is liable for a surplus or deficiency. Until a secured party has sold the collateral or discharged the debt by retaining the collateral in strict foreclosure, the debtor or any other secured party has a right to redeem by tendering all remaining obligations plus reasonable expenses incurred in repossessing the collateral.
cards.mnemonic: DISPOSE: Default, Notice, Sale OK, Proceeds: surplus to debtor, deficiency owed, Exception for A/C/P/N.
cards.atomizationNotes: Split into three children: (1) disposition & notice, (2) surplus/deficiency and exception, and (3) right to redeem.
cards.clozeLite: After default, a secured party may {{c1::dispose of collateral}} if the sale is {{c2::commercially reasonable}} and preceded by {{c3::reasonable authenticated notice}}; any {{c4::surplus goes to the debtor}} and {{c5::debtor is usually liable for a deficiency}}.

cards.subject: Secured Transactions
cards.topic: Strict Foreclosure
cards.rawHeader: Secured Transactions 019. Strict Foreclosure
cards.front: Strict Foreclosure – Overview
cards.backPlain: Strict foreclosure is an Article 9 remedy that allows a secured party, after default, to keep the collateral instead of selling it, in full or partial satisfaction of the debt. To use strict foreclosure, Article 9 requires debtor consent, proper authenticated notice to the debtor and certain other secured parties, and an opportunity for those parties to object within 20 days. If a timely objection is made, the secured party must dispose of the collateral by sale instead of keeping it. Special consumer-protection rules further restrict strict foreclosure in consumer transactions: a secured party generally cannot both keep consumer collateral in partial satisfaction and seek a deficiency, and where the debtor has paid at least 60% of a PMSI or other loan in consumer goods, the secured party must sell the collateral within 90 days of repossession unless the debtor waives the right to require a sale.
cards.frontPrompt: What is strict foreclosure under Article 9 at a high level, and what main categories of rules govern its use (including consumer protections)?
cards.cloze: Strict foreclosure is an Article 9 remedy that allows a {{c1::secured party}}, after {{c2::default}}, to {{c3::keep the collateral}} instead of selling it, in {{c4::full or partial satisfaction}} of the debt. Its use is governed by rules on {{c5::debtor consent}}, {{c6::authenticated notice}} and {{c7::20-day objection}} by the debtor and certain other secured parties, and {{c8::special consumer protections}} that limit partial satisfaction with deficiency and impose a {{c9::60%/90-day sale rule}} for certain consumer-goods loans.
cards.easyContent: Strict foreclosure lets a secured party, after default, keep the collateral instead of selling it, but only if Article 9’s consent, notice, and objection rules are satisfied, and subject to extra protections in consumer transactions.
cards.mediumContent: Strict foreclosure is an Article 9 remedy where, after default, the secured party keeps the collateral in full or partial satisfaction of the debt instead of selling it. Its use hinges on three buckets of rules: (1) the basic mechanics of retaining collateral to satisfy the debt; (2) debtor consent plus authenticated notice and a 20‑day opportunity for the debtor and certain other secured parties to object, with any timely objection forcing a sale instead; and (3) special consumer‑transaction limits, including a bar on partial satisfaction plus a deficiency and a 60%/90‑day sale rule for certain consumer‑goods loans.
cards.hardContent: Strict foreclosure is an Article 9 default remedy in which the secured party, rather than disposing of collateral, keeps it in full or partial satisfaction of the secured obligation. Using strict foreclosure requires (1) the basic decision by the secured party, after default, to retain collateral in satisfaction of the debt; (2) proper debtor consent and authenticated notice, including an opportunity for the debtor and certain competing secured parties to object within 20 days, with any timely objection forcing the secured party to dispose of the collateral by sale; and (3) compliance with special consumer‑protection limits. In consumer transactions, a secured party may not retain consumer collateral in partial satisfaction of the debt and then pursue a deficiency judgment, and if the debtor has paid at least 60% of a PMSI or other loan in consumer goods, the secured party must sell the collateral within 90 days after repossession unless the debtor waives the right to require a sale.
cards.mnemonic: "KEEP, CONSENT, CONSUMER"—keep collateral, get consent, honor consumer limits.
cards.atomizationNotes: Split into three children: (1) definition and basic mechanics of strict foreclosure, (2) consent and notice/objection requirements, and (3) special consumer-transaction limitations (no partial + deficiency; 60%/90-day rule).
