cards.subject: Secured Transactions
cards.topic: Liability for Article 9 Violations
cards.rawHeader: Secured Transactions 020. Liability for Article 9 Violations
cards.front: Liability for Article 9 Violations
cards.backPlain: 1. In general: Secured parties are liable for failure to comply with Article 9. Several remedies are available to the debtor. 1.1 Actual damages: The debtor can recover damages reasonably calculated to put the debtor in the position she would have been in had no violation occurred. 1.2 Statutory minimum damages for consumer goods: If the collateral involved is consumer goods, the debtor is entitled to at least 10% of the cash price of the goods plus the interest charges to be paid over the life of the loan. 1.3 Loss of deficiency judgment: The secured party may lose the right to a deficiency judgment for failure to comply. 1.3.1 Non-consumer transactions (rebuttable presumption rule): The value of the collateral seized is presumed equal to the debt owed unless the secured party proves otherwise. 1.3.2 Consumer transactions (three possible approaches): Courts take one of three approaches: 1) Apply the rebuttable presumption rule; 2) Deny the secured party any deficiency judgment; or 3) Allow the secured party to recover a deficiency minus the actual damages the debtor can prove.
cards.frontPrompt: What liability and remedies arise when a secured party violates Article 9, including actual damages, statutory damages for consumer goods, and the effect on deficiency judgments?
cards.cloze: 1. In general: {{c1::Secured parties}} are liable for failure to comply with {{c2::Article 9}}. Several remedies are available to the debtor. 1.1 {{c3::Actual damages}}: The debtor can recover damages reasonably calculated to put the debtor in the position she would have been in {{c4::had no violation occurred}}. 1.2 {{c5::Statutory minimum damages for consumer goods}}: If the collateral involved is {{c6::consumer goods}}, the debtor is entitled to at least {{c7::10% of the cash price}} of the goods plus the {{c8::interest charges to be paid over the life of the loan}}. 1.3 {{c9::Loss of deficiency judgment}}: The secured party may lose the right to a deficiency judgment for failure to comply. 1.3.1 {{c10::Non-consumer transactions (rebuttable presumption rule)}}: The value of the collateral seized is {{c11::presumed equal to the debt owed}} unless the secured party proves otherwise. 1.3.2 {{c12::Consumer transactions (three possible approaches)}}: Courts take one of three approaches: 1) Apply the {{c13::rebuttable presumption rule}}; 2) {{c14::Deny the secured party any deficiency judgment}}; or 3) Allow the secured party to recover a {{c15::deficiency minus the actual damages the debtor can prove}}.
cards.easyContent: If a secured party violates Article 9, the debtor can recover actual damages, may get statutory minimum damages for consumer-goods collateral, and the secured party may lose or have limits placed on any claimed deficiency judgment.
cards.mediumContent: Article 9 makes secured parties liable when they fail to comply with its requirements. The debtor may recover actual damages sufficient to place her in the position she would have occupied absent the violation. For collateral that is consumer goods, the debtor is also entitled to statutory minimum damages of at least 10% of the cash price plus all interest charges over the life of the loan. The secured party may lose the right to a deficiency judgment; in non-consumer cases, courts typically apply the rebuttable presumption rule that the collateral’s value equals the debt unless the secured party proves otherwise. In consumer cases, courts either apply the rebuttable presumption rule, deny any deficiency, or allow a deficiency reduced by the debtor’s provable actual damages.
cards.hardContent: When a secured party fails to comply with Article 9, it is liable to the debtor. The debtor may recover actual damages designed to put her in the position she would have occupied had there been no violation. If the collateral is consumer goods, the debtor is also entitled to statutory minimum damages of at least 10% of the cash price of the goods plus the interest charges due over the life of the loan. In addition, noncompliance can affect the secured party’s right to a deficiency judgment. In non-consumer transactions, most jurisdictions apply the rebuttable presumption rule, presuming the value of the seized collateral equals the debt unless the secured party proves a lower value. In consumer transactions, courts follow one of three approaches: (1) apply the rebuttable presumption rule; (2) deny the secured party any deficiency judgment; or (3) permit a deficiency but reduce it by the amount of actual damages the debtor can prove.
cards.mnemonic: A-S-L: Actual, Statutory, Loss of deficiency.
cards.clozeLite: Article 9 violations make a secured party liable for {{c1::actual damages}}, {{c2::statutory minimum damages for consumer-goods collateral}}, and {{c3::loss or limits on deficiency judgments}}.

cards.subject: Secured Transactions
cards.topic: Governing Law and Debtor Location
cards.rawHeader: Secured Transactions 021. Governing Law and Debtor Location
cards.front: Governing Law and Debtor Location
cards.backPlain: 1. Governing law: As a general rule, the law of the state where the debtor is located governs perfection of a security interest. 1.1 Individual debtors: The debtor is located at the place of the debtor’s principal residence. 1.2 Registered organizational debtors: The debtor is located in the state under whose laws it is organized (for example, where the articles of incorporation are filed). 1.3 Unregistered organizational debtors (for example, a partnership): The debtor is located at its place of business, or, if it has more than one place of business, at its chief executive office. 2. Common exceptions to the general governing-law rule: 2.1 Certificate of title goods: Where goods are covered by a certificate of title (e.g., an automobile), the law of the state issuing the most recent certificate of title governs perfection. 2.2 Agricultural liens: Perfection is governed by the law of the state in which the farm product is located. 2.3 Possessory security interests: Perfection is governed by the law of the state in which the collateral is located.
cards.frontPrompt: Under Article 9, what law governs perfection of a security interest based on the debtor’s location, and what are the main exceptions for certificates of title, agricultural liens, and possessory interests?

Common {{c12::exceptions}} to the general governing-law rule: 2.1 {{c13::Certificate of title goods}}: Where goods are covered by a certificate of title (e.g., an automobile), the law of the state issuing the {{c14::most recent certificate of title}} governs perfection. 2.2 {{c15::Agricultural liens}}: Perfection is governed by the law of the state in which the {{c16::farm product}} is located. 2.3 {{c17::Possessory security interests}}: Perfection is governed by the law of the state in which the {{c18::collateral is located}}.
cards.easyContent: Generally, the law of the debtor’s location governs perfection of a security interest, but for certificate-of-title goods, agricultural liens, and possessory security interests, perfection is governed by the law of where the collateral or farm product is titled or located.
cards.mediumContent: Article 9 generally applies the law of the state where the debtor is located to questions of perfection. An individual debtor is located at her principal residence; a registered organization is located in its state of organization; and an unregistered organization, such as a partnership, is located at its place of business or, if it has several, at its chief executive office. Important exceptions: for certificate-of-title goods, the law of the state issuing the most recent title certificate governs; for agricultural liens, the law of the state where the farm product is located governs; and for possessory security interests, the law of the state where the collateral is physically located governs perfection.
cards.hardContent: Under Article 9’s general governing-law rule, the law of the state where the debtor is located governs the perfection of a security interest. An individual debtor is located at her principal residence. A registered organization is located in the state under whose laws it is organized, typically the state where its articles of incorporation or similar chartering documents are filed. An unregistered organization, such as a general partnership, is located at its place of business or, if it has more than one place of business, at its chief executive office. There are key exceptions: (1) for certificate-of-title goods such as automobiles, the law of the state issuing the most recent certificate of title controls perfection; (2) for agricultural liens, the applicable law is that of the state in which the farm product is located; and (3) for possessory security interests, the law of the state where the collateral is physically located governs perfection.
cards.mnemonic: Locate the DEBTOR—unless you must locate the THING.
cards.clozeLite: Under Article 9, {{c1::the law of the debtor’s location}} generally governs {{c2::perfection}}; exceptions: {{c3::certificate-of-title goods}}, {{c4::agricultural liens}}, and {{c5::possessory security interests}} follow the law where the item is titled or located.

cards.subject: Secured Transactions
cards.topic: Interstate Movement of Debtor or Collateral
cards.rawHeader: Secured Transactions 022. Interstate Movement of Debtor or Collateral
cards.front: Interstate Movement of Debtor or Collateral – Overview
cards.backPlain: Article 9 provides temporary perfection when the debtor or collateral crosses state lines, but the secured party must act within specific time limits or risk losing perfection and priority. 1. General rule 1.1 When the debtor or the collateral moves from one state to another, a security interest perfected in the original state generally remains temporarily perfected. 1.2 This temporary perfection gives the secured party time to perfect in the new state. 1.3 If the secured party fails to perfect in the new state within the applicable period, the security interest becomes unperfected and loses its original priority date. 2. Key scenarios 2.1 Debtor relocation: perfection in the old state continues for four months after the debtor’s move; the secured party must perfect in the new state within that four‑month window to maintain continuous perfection and priority. 2.2 Movement of collateral perfected by possession: moving the collateral does not destroy perfection so long as possession would perfect the interest under the new state’s law. 2.3 Titled vehicles: if a vehicle covered by a certificate of title moves to a new state that issues a new certificate, the original perfected interest continues for as long as it would have if no new title had been issued. 2.4 New debtor in a different state: when collateral is transferred to a new debtor in another state who becomes bound by the security agreement, the original perfection continues until one year after the transfer or until perfection in the original state lapses, whichever occurs first.
cards.frontPrompt: What are the main Article 9 rules for temporary perfection and priority when the debtor or collateral moves to another state, and what key time limits apply?
cards.cloze: Article 9 provides {{c1::temporary perfection}} when the {{c2::debtor or collateral moves to another state}}, but the secured party must act within specific {{c3::time limits}} or risk losing {{c4::perfection}} and {{c5::priority}}. Key scenarios: - {{c6::Debtor relocation}}: prior perfection continues for {{c7::four months}} after the move; the secured party must perfect in the new state within that four‑month window. - {{c8::Movement of collateral perfected by possession}}: perfection continues if {{c9::possession would perfect under the new state’s law}}. - {{c10::Titled vehicles}}: if a new certificate of title is issued in another state, the original perfection lasts as long as it would have {{c11::had the new title not been issued}}. - {{c12::New debtor in a different state}}: original perfection continues until {{c13::one year after the transfer}} or until {{c14::perfection in the original state lapses}}, whichever occurs first.
cards.easyContent: When a debtor or collateral crosses state lines, Article 9 gives temporary perfection so the secured party can perfect in the new state. The main time limits are four months after debtor relocation, continued perfection while possession would still perfect in the new state, continuation of perfection despite a new certificate of title, and one year after transfer to a new debtor in a different state (or until original perfection lapses).
cards.mediumContent: Article 9’s interstate movement rules give a secured party temporary perfection while either the debtor or collateral moves to another state. A security interest perfected in the original state remains temporarily perfected, but if the secured party does not perfect under the new state’s law within the applicable time, the interest becomes unperfected and loses its original priority date. Key scenarios: (1) debtor relocation, where perfection continues for four months and the secured party must perfect in the new state within that period for continuous perfection and priority; (2) movement of collateral perfected by possession, where perfection continues as long as possession would perfect the interest under the new state’s law; (3) certificate‑of‑title goods that move and receive a new title, where the original perfection continues as long as it would have if no new title were issued; and (4) transfers of collateral to a new debtor in a different state, where original perfection continues for one year after the transfer or until perfection in the original state lapses, whichever comes first.
cards.hardContent: Article 9 treats interstate movement of debtors and collateral by granting temporary perfection that allows secured parties to adjust to a new jurisdiction without immediately losing priority. When the debtor or the collateral moves to another state, a security interest perfected in the original state generally remains temporarily perfected, but if the secured party fails to perfect under the new state’s law within the applicable time, the interest becomes unperfected and loses its original priority date. The main scenarios are: (1) debtor relocation—perfection under the law of the original state continues for four months after relocation; the secured party must perfect in the new debtor’s state within that four‑month period to maintain continuous perfection and original priority; (2) movement of collateral perfected by a possessory security interest—if collateral perfected by possession in one state is moved to another, the interest remains perfected as long as possession would perfect the interest under the new state’s law; (3) cars or other certificate‑of‑title goods—if the goods move to a new state and a new certificate of title is issued, the original perfected interest continues for as long as it would have if the new title had not been issued; and (4) transfers to a new debtor in another state—when a new debtor located in a different state becomes bound by an existing security agreement and collateral is transferred, the original security interest remains perfected until one year after the transfer or until perfection in the original state lapses, whichever occurs first.
cards.mnemonic: "4 for MOVING, 1 for NEW"—4 months moving debtor, 1 year new debtor.
cards.atomizationNotes: Split into three children: (1) general temporary perfection and debtor relocation (four‑month rule), (2) movement of collateral with possessory interests and certificate‑of‑title vehicles, and (3) transfers to new debtors in other states (one‑year rule).

cards.subject: Secured Transactions
cards.topic: Collateral Classification – Tangible Goods
cards.rawHeader: Secured Transactions 003-1. Collateral Classification – Tangible Goods
cards.front: Collateral Classification – Tangible Goods
cards.backPlain: Tangible goods are physical goods that can serve as collateral under Article 9, and they are divided into four main categories: 1. Farming goods: - Items used or produced in farming. - Examples: crops, livestock, farm products. 2. Consumer goods: - Goods used or bought primarily for personal, family, or household purposes. - Examples: home furniture, a family car, household electronics. 3. Inventory: - Goods held by a business for sale or lease, or furnished under a contract of service. - Includes raw materials, work in progress, and materials consumed in business (like fuel or office supplies) if held for short‑term use or turnover. 4. Equipment: - Catchall category for tangible goods that do not fit as farming goods, consumer goods, or inventory. - Typically long‑term business goods used in operations. - Examples: factory machinery, office computers, restaurant ovens. Correctly classifying tangible goods as farming goods, consumer goods, inventory, or equipment is essential because different rules may apply to perfection and priority for each type.
cards.frontPrompt: In Article 9, what are the four categories of tangible goods used as collateral, and how is each defined?
cards.cloze: Tangible goods are {{c1::physical goods}} that can serve as collateral under Article 9, and they are divided into four main categories: 1. {{c2::Farming goods}}: - Items {{c3::used or produced in farming}}. - Examples: {{c4::crops, livestock, farm products}}. 2. {{c5::Consumer goods}}: - Goods used or bought primarily for {{c6::personal, family, or household}} purposes. - Examples: {{c7::home furniture, a family car, household electronics}}. 3. {{c8::Inventory}}: - Goods held by a business for {{c9::sale or lease}}, or furnished under a {{c10::contract of service}}. - Includes raw materials, work in progress, and materials consumed in business if held for {{c11::short‑term use or turnover}}. 4. {{c12::Equipment}}: - {{c13::Catchall category}} for tangible goods that do not fit as farming goods, consumer goods, or inventory. - Typically {{c14::long‑term business goods}} used in operations (e.g., {{c15::factory machinery, office computers, restaurant ovens}}).
cards.easyContent: Tangible collateral under Article 9 is divided into four types: (1) farming goods (used or produced in farming), (2) consumer goods (for personal, family, or household use), (3) inventory (goods held for sale or lease or short‑term business use), and (4) equipment (a catchall for other business goods, like machinery).
cards.mediumContent: Article 9 classifies physical goods into four main categories: (1) farming goods—items used or produced in farming, like crops and livestock; (2) consumer goods—goods used primarily for personal, family, or household purposes; (3) inventory—goods a business holds for sale or lease, or that are quickly consumed or turned over in business operations; and (4) equipment—a residual category for tangible business goods not fitting the other types, typically long‑term operating assets, like factory machinery or office computers.
cards.hardContent: Tangible collateral is central to Article 9 and is divided into four categories that affect how a security interest is perfected and prioritized: 1. Farming goods: goods used or produced in farming, including crops, livestock, and other farm products. 2. Consumer goods: goods primarily used or bought for personal, family, or household purposes, such as home furniture and a family vehicle. 3. Inventory: goods a business holds for sale or lease, or furnishes under a service contract, including raw materials, goods in process, and items consumed in a short time frame in business operations (e.g., fuel, office supplies) when they are part of the business’s turnover. 4. Equipment: a catchall for tangible goods that are not farming goods, consumer goods, or inventory. These are typically durable goods used in a business’s long‑term operations, such as factory machines, restaurant ovens, and office equipment. Accurately distinguishing between inventory and equipment, and between consumer goods and other categories, is often tested and can change the applicable perfection and priority rules.
cards.mnemonic: For tangible goods, think F‑CIE: Farming goods, Consumer goods, Inventory, Equipment.

cards.subject: Secured Transactions
cards.topic: Collateral Classification – Intangible and Quasi‑Tangible Property
cards.rawHeader: Secured Transactions 003-2. Collateral Classification – Intangible and Quasi‑Tangible Property
cards.front: Collateral Classification – Intangible and Quasi‑Tangible Property
cards.backPlain: Intangible and quasi‑tangible property under Article 9 consists largely of rights to payment or other non‑physical personal property interests. Common categories include: 1. Instruments: - Writings that evidence a right to be paid money. - Examples: promissory notes, checks. 2. Documents: - Writings that evidence a right to receive goods. - Examples: bills of lading, warehouse receipts. 3. Chattel paper: - A record (written or electronic) evidencing BOTH: (1) a monetary obligation, and (2) a security interest in specific goods or a lease of specific goods. - Example: a retail installment sales contract that includes a promissory note and a security interest in the goods sold. 4. Accounts: - A right to payment not evidenced by an instrument or chattel paper (i.e., accounts receivable). - Example: money owed to a dentist after treating a patient. - Excludes: deposit accounts, investment property, and commercial tort claims. 5. Deposit accounts: - Bank accounts. - Article 9 generally covers non‑consumer deposit accounts as original collateral. 6. General intangibles: - Residual category for personal property not fitting another classification. - Examples: patent rights, copyrights, trademarks, software, goodwill. Properly distinguishing among instruments, documents, chattel paper, accounts, deposit accounts, and general intangibles is crucial for determining how a security interest can be attached, perfected (e.g., by filing or control), and prioritized.
cards.frontPrompt: Under Article 9, what are the main types of intangible and quasi‑tangible collateral, and how is each defined?
cards.cloze: Intangible and quasi‑tangible property under Article 9 consists largely of {{c1::rights to payment}} or other {{c2::non‑physical personal property}} interests. Common categories include: 1. {{c3::Instruments}}: - Writings that evidence a right to be {{c4::paid money}}. - Examples: {{c5::promissory notes, checks}}. 2. {{c6::Documents}}: - Writings that evidence a right to {{c7::receive goods}}. - Examples: {{c8::bills of lading, warehouse receipts}}. 3. {{c9::Chattel paper}}: - A record evidencing BOTH: (1) a {{c10::monetary obligation}}, and (2) a {{c11::security interest in specific goods}} or a {{c12::lease of specific goods}}. - Example: {{c13::a retail installment sales contract including a promissory note and a security interest in the goods sold}}. 4. {{c14::Accounts}}: - A right to payment not evidenced by an instrument or chattel paper (i.e., {{c15::accounts receivable}}). - Example: {{c16::money owed to a dentist after treating a patient}}. - Excludes: {{c17::deposit accounts, investment property, and commercial tort claims}}. 5. {{c18::Deposit accounts}}: - {{c19::Bank accounts}}, generally non‑consumer when treated as original collateral under Article 9. 6. {{c20::General intangibles}}: - Residual category for {{c21::personal property not fitting another classification}}. - Examples: {{c22::patent rights, copyrights, trademarks, software, goodwill}}.
cards.easyContent: Important intangible or quasi‑tangible collateral types include: instruments (rights to be paid money in a writing like a note), documents (rights to receive goods, like a warehouse receipt), chattel paper (a record showing both a monetary obligation and a security interest in or lease of goods), accounts (rights to payment not in an instrument or chattel paper), deposit accounts (bank accounts), and general intangibles (a catchall for things like patents and software).
cards.mediumContent: Article 9 covers several key types of intangible and quasi‑tangible collateral: (1) instruments—writings evidencing a right to be paid money, such as promissory notes and checks; (2) documents—writings evidencing a right to receive goods, like bills of lading or warehouse receipts; (3) chattel paper—a record that combines a monetary obligation with a security interest in, or a lease of, specific goods; (4) accounts—rights to payment (accounts receivable) not evidenced by an instrument or chattel paper, excluding deposit accounts, investment property, and commercial tort claims; (5) deposit accounts—bank accounts, usually non‑consumer when original collateral; and (6) general intangibles—the residual class for personal property that doesn’t fit other categories, including IP rights and software.
cards.hardContent: Article 9’s treatment of intangible and quasi‑tangible collateral depends on precise classification: 1. Instruments: writings evidencing a right to be paid money, such as promissory notes and checks. These are typically negotiable or similar payment rights. 2. Documents: writings evidencing a right to receive goods, including bills of lading and warehouse receipts. Control or possession can be important for perfection. 3. Chattel paper: a record (paper or electronic) evidencing both (i) a monetary obligation and (ii) a security interest in, or lease of, specific goods—for example, a retail installment contract that includes the buyer’s promise to pay and grants the seller a security interest in the purchased item. 4. Accounts: rights to payment for goods sold or services rendered that are not evidenced by an instrument or chattel paper; essentially, accounts receivable. An example is money owed to a dentist after providing services. Accounts expressly exclude deposit accounts, investment property, and commercial tort claims. 5. Deposit accounts: bank accounts. Article 9 generally covers non‑consumer deposit accounts as original collateral, with perfection usually requiring control. 6. General intangibles: a broad residual category for personal property that does not qualify as goods, instruments, documents, chattel paper, accounts, deposit accounts, or other specifically defined collateral. Examples include patents, copyrights, trademarks, software, and goodwill. Recognizing whether a right to payment is an instrument, chattel paper, or an account—and whether an asset falls into general intangibles—is critical for determining the proper method of attachment, perfection (such as filing vs. control), and priority.

cards.subject: Secured Transactions
cards.topic: Perfection by Filing – Financing Statement Requirements
cards.rawHeader: Secured Transactions 008-1. Perfection by Filing – Financing Statement Requirements
cards.front: Perfection by Filing – Financing Statement Requirements
cards.backPlain: Perfection by filing a financing statement: 1. Filing as a primary method of perfection: 1.1 A secured party can usually perfect a security interest by filing a financing statement with the appropriate state filing office (often the secretary of state in the debtor’s jurisdiction). 2. Required contents of a financing statement: 2.1 Identify the debtor: 2.1.1 The debtor’s name must exactly match the name on official records. 2.1.2 For a business organization, the name must match the Articles of Incorporation or other organizing document. 2.2 Identify the secured party/creditor. 2.3 Contain an adequate description of the collateral: 2.3.1 The description must reasonably identify the collateral (e.g., by category, type, or specific listing). 2.4 Be authorized by the debtor: 2.4.1 Debtor authorization is usually satisfied when the debtor signs the security agreement. 2.4.2 Unauthorized filings are ineffective. 3. Effect of proper filing: 3.1 If the financing statement meets these requirements and is filed in the proper place, the secured party’s security interest is perfected (subject to any additional special rules for specific collateral types).
cards.frontPrompt: How is a security interest perfected by filing a financing statement under Article 9, and what are the key formal requirements for a valid financing statement?
cards.cloze: Perfection by filing a {{c1::financing statement}}: 1. Filing as a primary method: 1.1 A secured party can usually perfect a security interest by filing with the appropriate {{c2::state filing office}}. 2. Required contents of a financing statement: 2.1 Identify the {{c3::debtor}}: 2.1.1 The debtor’s name must exactly match {{c4::official records}}. 2.1.2 For a business organization, the name must match the {{c5::Articles of Incorporation}} or other organizing document. 2.2 Identify the {{c6::secured party/creditor}}. 2.3 Contain an adequate {{c7::description of the collateral}} that reasonably identifies it. 2.4 Be {{c8::authorized by the debtor}}: 2.4.1 Authorization is usually satisfied when the debtor signs the {{c9::security agreement}}. 3. Effect of proper filing: 3.1 If these requirements are met and filing is in the proper place, the security interest is {{c10::perfected}}.
cards.easyContent: A security interest can be perfected by filing a financing statement with the proper state office. The statement must correctly name the debtor, identify the secured party, reasonably describe the collateral, and be authorized by the debtor (usually through signing the security agreement).
cards.mediumContent: Perfection by filing is the standard method. A valid financing statement must: (1) identify the debtor using the exact name from official records (for entities, from the Articles of Incorporation or organizing document); (2) identify the secured party; (3) contain an adequate description of the collateral that reasonably identifies it; and (4) be authorized by the debtor, typically via the signed security agreement. Once properly filed in the correct office, the security interest is perfected.
cards.hardContent: Under Article 9, a secured party usually perfects a security interest by filing a financing statement with the appropriate state office. The filing is effective only if formal requirements are met. The financing statement must identify the debtor by the exact name appearing in official records; for a business entity, the controlling name is that in the Articles of Incorporation or similar organizing document. The statement must also identify the secured party or representative and contain an adequate description of the collateral that reasonably identifies what is covered. Finally, the filing must be authorized by the debtor, which is generally satisfied when the debtor signs the security agreement. An unauthorized filing is ineffective. When these conditions are met and the filing is made in the proper place, the secured party’s security interest becomes perfected, subject to special rules for particular collateral types.
cards.mnemonic: Filing needs D-S-C-A: Debtor, Secured party, Collateral, Authorization.
cards.clozeLite: A financing statement is valid only if it {{c1::uses the debtor’s exact legal name}}, {{c2::identifies the secured party}}, {{c3::reasonably describes the collateral}}, and {{c4::is authorized by the debtor}}.

cards.subject: Secured Transactions
cards.topic: Perfection by Possession – What Can and Cannot Be Perfected
cards.rawHeader: Secured Transactions 008-2. Perfection by Possession – What Can and Cannot Be Perfected
cards.front: Perfection by Possession – Scope and Limits
cards.backPlain: Perfection by possession: 1. General rule: 1.1 A secured party may perfect a security interest in many types of collateral simply by taking possession of the collateral. 1.2 Possession is common where the nature of the collateral lends itself to physical control. 2. Collateral that can be perfected by possession (examples): 2.1 Goods (e.g., a pawnshop situation where the creditor holds the item). 2.2 Negotiable documents. 2.3 Instruments. 3. Collateral that cannot be perfected by possession: 3.1 Certain intangible or quasi-intangible collateral cannot practically be possessed. 3.2 Examples include: 3.2.1 Accounts. 3.2.2 Certificate-of-title goods (which are generally perfected by notation on the title instead). 3.2.3 Electronic chattel paper. 3.2.4 General intangibles. 4. Effect of perfection by possession: 4.1 When Article 9 allows it, taking and maintaining possession perfects the security interest as long as possession continues.
cards.frontPrompt: When can a secured party perfect a security interest by possession under Article 9, which types of collateral are suited to perfection by possession, and which types cannot be perfected this way?
cards.cloze: Perfection by {{c1::possession}}: 1. General rule: 1.1 A secured party may perfect a security interest by taking {{c2::possession}} of many types of collateral. 2. Collateral that can be perfected by possession (examples): 2.1 {{c3::Goods}} (e.g., a pawnshop situation). 2.2 {{c4::Negotiable documents}}. 2.3 {{c5::Instruments}}. 3. Effect: 4.1 When allowed, maintaining {{c10::possession}} of the collateral perfects the security interest as long as possession continues.
cards.easyContent: A secured party can perfect by possession for collateral that can physically be held, like goods, negotiable documents, and instruments. Intangibles such as accounts, electronic chattel paper, general intangibles, and certificate-of-title goods (which use title notation instead) cannot be perfected by possession.
cards.mediumContent: Perfection by possession is permitted for many tangible or quasi-tangible assets. Typical examples are goods (such as items held by a pawnshop), negotiable documents, and instruments. In contrast, intangibles and certain quasi-intangibles, like accounts, electronic chattel paper, general intangibles, and certificate-of-title goods, cannot be perfected by possession; those require filing or special titling rules. When Article 9 authorizes it, taking and maintaining possession of the collateral perfects the security interest for as long as possession continues.
cards.hardContent: Article 9 allows a secured party to perfect a security interest by taking possession of certain types of collateral whose nature lends itself to physical control. Common examples include goods, such as items pledged in a pawnshop arrangement, negotiable documents, and instruments; perfection is maintained so long as the secured party retains possession. However, many forms of collateral cannot be perfected by possession because they are intangible or quasi-intangible. These include accounts, certificate-of-title goods (which are generally perfected instead by lien notation on the title), electronic chattel paper, and general intangibles. For such collateral, perfection typically requires filing or compliance with a more specific statutory regime, not mere physical control.

cards.clozeLite: Perfection by {{c1::possession}} works for {{c2::goods, negotiable documents, and instruments}}, but not for {{c3::accounts, electronic chattel paper, general intangibles, or certificate-of-title goods}}.

cards.subject: Secured Transactions
cards.topic: Automatic Perfection and PMSIs
cards.rawHeader: Secured Transactions 008-3. Automatic Perfection and PMSIs
cards.front: Automatic Perfection and PMSIs
cards.backPlain: Automatic perfection and PMSIs: 1. Automatic perfection: 1.1 In some transactions, once the security interest has attached to the collateral, perfection occurs automatically without any further act such as filing or possession. 1.2 Automatic perfection is the exception, not the rule, and typically applies only in limited, defined circumstances. 2. Purchase-money security interests (PMSIs): 2.1 A purchase-money security interest is a security interest where: 2.1.1 The creditor sells goods to the debtor on credit and retains a security interest in the goods; and/or 2.1.2 The creditor advances funds to the debtor so the debtor can buy specific goods, and the creditor takes a security interest in those same goods. 2.2 Certain PMSIs automatically perfect upon attachment: 2.2.1 For example, a PMSI in consumer goods is often automatically perfected when the security interest attaches (no filing required), subject to statutory exceptions and special rules. 3. Relationship between attachment and perfection: 3.1 For automatically perfected interests, the secured party’s rights are perfected at the moment of attachment, giving the secured party immediate priority benefits without additional steps.
cards.frontPrompt: What is automatic perfection under Article 9, how is a purchase-money security interest (PMSI) defined, and in what way do some PMSIs perfect automatically upon attachment?
cards.cloze: Automatic perfection and {{c1::purchase-money security interests (PMSIs)}}: 1. Automatic perfection: 1.1 In some transactions, once the security interest has {{c2::attached}} to the collateral, perfection occurs {{c3::automatically}} without filing or possession. 2. PMSIs: 2.1 A PMSI exists where a creditor: 2.1.1 {{c4::Sells goods}} to the debtor on credit and retains a security interest in those goods; and/or 2.1.2 {{c5::Advances funds}} to the debtor to buy specific goods and takes a security interest in those same goods. 2.2 Certain PMSIs automatically perfect upon attachment: 2.2.1 A classic example is a PMSI in {{c6::consumer goods}}, which is often automatically perfected when the interest attaches (subject to exceptions). 3. Effect: 3.1 For automatically perfected SIs, the secured party is {{c7::perfected at the moment of attachment}}, gaining priority benefits without additional steps.
cards.easyContent: Some security interests perfect automatically as soon as they attach, without filing or possession. This often happens with certain purchase-money security interests (PMSIs), such as a PMSI in consumer goods, where the creditor finances or sells the goods and keeps a security interest in them.
cards.mediumContent: Automatic perfection is a limited exception to the general requirement of filing or possession. It commonly applies to certain purchase-money security interests (PMSIs), where the creditor either sells goods to the debtor on credit or advances money so the debtor can buy specific goods, and then takes a security interest in those goods. In many cases, a PMSI in consumer goods is automatically perfected at the moment the security interest attaches, so the secured party need not file. Some PMSIs in other types of collateral may require filing or have special timing rules.
cards.hardContent: Under Article 9, most security interests must be perfected by filing or possession, but a narrow class of interests are perfected automatically upon attachment. Automatic perfection is particularly associated with purchase-money security interests (PMSIs). A PMSI arises when a creditor either sells goods to the debtor on credit and retains a security interest in those goods, or advances funds enabling the debtor to acquire specific goods and takes a security interest in those goods. In several common scenarios—most notably a PMSI in consumer goods—the PMSI is automatically perfected as soon as the security interest attaches, without any filing or further act by the secured party. This immediate perfection grants the secured creditor priority advantages while relieving them of the burden of filing, though statutory exceptions and special rules may apply for certain types of collateral or competing claimants.

cards.subject: Secured Transactions
cards.topic: Perfection of Security Interests in Motor Vehicles
cards.rawHeader: Secured Transactions 008-4. Perfection of Security Interests in Motor Vehicles
cards.front: Perfection of Security Interests in Motor Vehicles
cards.backPlain: Perfection of security interests in motor vehicles: 1. Certificate-of-title system: 1.1 Many jurisdictions treat motor vehicles as "certificate-of-title goods." 1.2 These vehicles are governed by a special titling statute rather than ordinary Article 9 filing rules. 2. General rule for perfection in motor vehicles: 2.1 Security interests in motor vehicles covered by a certificate of title are generally perfected by notation of the lien on the vehicle’s certificate of title. 2.2 Filing a standard Article 9 financing statement is usually not effective to perfect against third parties if the statute requires title notation instead. 3. Practical effect: 3.1 To perfect an SI in a titled motor vehicle, the secured party must ensure that its lien is properly recorded on the certificate of title in accordance with the applicable statute. 3.2 Failure to have the lien noted on the title risks leaving the security interest unperfected as against other creditors and purchasers.
cards.frontPrompt: How are security interests in motor vehicles that are subject to a certificate-of-title statute generally perfected, and why is notation on the title usually required instead of a standard Article 9 filing?
cards.cloze: Perfection of security interests in {{c1::motor vehicles}}: 1. Certificate-of-title system: 1.1 Many vehicles are treated as {{c2::certificate-of-title goods}} under special titling statutes. 2. General rule: 2.1 A security interest in a motor vehicle covered by a certificate of title is generally perfected by {{c3::notation of the lien on the vehicle’s certificate of title}}. 2.2 A standard Article 9 {{c4::financing statement}} is usually not sufficient if the statute requires title notation instead. 3. Practical effect: 3.1 The secured party must ensure its lien is properly {{c5::recorded on the title}} to achieve perfection and priority over other creditors and purchasers.
cards.easyContent: For most cars and other titled vehicles, a security interest is perfected not by filing a UCC financing statement but by having the lien noted on the vehicle’s certificate of title under the state’s title statute.
cards.mediumContent: Motor vehicles subject to a certificate-of-title statute are typically perfected through that titling system, not by ordinary UCC filing. The usual rule is that a security interest is perfected by notation of the lien on the vehicle’s certificate of title. Filing a standard Article 9 financing statement normally will not perfect the interest against third parties if title notation is required.
cards.hardContent: Many motor vehicles are classified as certificate-of-title goods and are governed by a specialized certificate-of-title statute rather than ordinary Article 9 filing rules. Under these regimes, a security interest in a covered motor vehicle is generally perfected only when the lien is properly noted on the vehicle’s certificate of title. Filing a standard Article 9 financing statement is typically ineffective to establish perfection against third parties if the statute requires title notation as the exclusive method. Accordingly, to perfect and maintain priority in a motor-vehicle collateral, the secured party must comply with the titling procedures to ensure that its lien is recorded on the certificate of title; otherwise, the interest may remain unperfected as to other creditors or purchasers.
cards.mnemonic: Cars need TITLES: Titled Interest Typically Listed on Existing certificate.
cards.clozeLite: For {{c1::certificate-of-title}} vehicles, a security interest is perfected by {{c2::notation of the lien on the certificate of title}}, and {{c3::Article 9 filing alone is ineffective}}.

cards.subject: Secured Transactions
cards.topic: Fixtures – Definition, Fixture Filing, Priority, and PMSI Exception
cards.rawHeader: Secured Transactions 014-1. Fixtures – Definition, Fixture Filing, Priority, and PMSI Exception
cards.front: Fixtures – Definition, Fixture Filing, Priority, and PMSI Exception
cards.backPlain: 1. Fixtures – Definition 1.1 Fixtures are goods that become attached to real property such that an interest in them arises under real property law. 2. Fixture Filing 2.1 A fixture filing is a financing statement filed where a mortgage on the related real property would be recorded. 3. General Priority Rule (Fixtures vs. Real Property Interests) 3.1 As between a security interest in fixtures and an interest in the real property to which they are affixed, priority is governed by a first‑to‑file‑or‑record rule. 3.2 The party who is first to file a valid fixture filing or first to record its real property interest takes priority. 4. PMSI Exception in Fixtures 4.1 A purchase‑money secured party in fixtures can obtain super‑priority. 4.2 If a PMSI secured party makes a proper fixture filing within 20 days after the goods become fixtures (affixation), that PMSI has priority even over a real property interest that was recorded before the goods were affixed. 5. Summary 5.1 Default rule: First to file a fixture filing or record the real property interest wins. 5.2 Exception: A PMSI in fixtures that files within 20 days of affixation can trump an earlier recorded real property interest.
cards.frontPrompt: What is a fixture under Article 9, what is a fixture filing, and how do the general first‑to‑file‑or‑record rule and the PMSI 20‑day exception determine priority between a security interest in fixtures and real property interests?
cards.cloze: 1. {{c1::Fixtures – Definition}} 1.1 Fixtures are {{c2::goods that become attached to real property}} such that an interest in them arises under {{c3::real property law}}. 2. {{c4::Fixture Filing}} 2.1 A fixture filing is a {{c5::financing statement}} filed where a {{c6::mortgage on the related real property}} would be recorded. 3. {{c7::General Priority Rule (Fixtures vs. Real Property Interests)}} 3.1 Priority is governed by a {{c8::first‑to‑file‑or‑record}} rule. 3.2 The party who is first to {{c9::file a fixture filing}} or first to {{c10::record its real property interest}} takes priority. 4. {{c11::PMSI Exception in Fixtures}} 4.1 A {{c12::purchase‑money secured party}} in fixtures can obtain super‑priority. 4.2 If the PMSI secured party makes a fixture filing within {{c13::20 days}} after the goods become fixtures ({{c14::affixation}}), the PMSI {{c15::prevails even over a prior recorded real property interest}}. 5. {{c16::Summary}} 5.1 Default: {{c17::First to file or record wins}}. 5.2 Exception: {{c18::Timely PMSI fixture filing (within 20 days) beats earlier real property interests}}.
cards.easyContent: Fixtures are goods attached to real property. Priority between a fixture security interest and a real property interest usually goes to the first to file or record—but a PMSI creditor that files a fixture filing within 20 days of affixation takes priority even over an earlier recorded real property interest.
cards.mediumContent: A fixture is a good attached to real property such that an interest in it arises under real property law. To perfect in fixtures against real property interests, the secured party generally must make a fixture filing, which is a financing statement filed where a mortgage on the real property would be recorded. As between a fixture security interest and a real property interest, the first to file a fixture filing or to record the real property interest usually has priority. However, a purchase‑money secured party who files a proper fixture filing within 20 days after the goods become fixtures takes priority even over a real property interest that was recorded before affixation.
cards.hardContent: Fixtures are goods that become attached to real property so that they are treated under real property law. To compete with real property interests, a secured party in fixtures typically must file a fixture filing, which is a financing statement filed in the local real estate records where a mortgage on the property would be recorded. Priority between a security interest in fixtures and an interest in the underlying real property is governed by a first‑to‑file‑or‑record regime: whichever party first files a fixture filing (for the fixture security interest) or records its real property interest generally prevails. There is a PMSI super‑priority exception: a purchase‑money secured party in fixtures that files a proper fixture filing within 20 days after the goods become fixtures will take priority over even a previously recorded real property interest.
cards.mnemonic: Fixtures: First to File, PMSI in 20.
cards.clozeLite: A {{c1::fixture}} is a good attached to real property; priority is {{c2::first to file or record}}, unless a {{c3::PMSI with a fixture filing}} is made within {{c4::20 days of affixation}}.

cards.subject: Secured Transactions
cards.topic: Accessions – Definition and Continuation of Security Interest
cards.rawHeader: Secured Transactions 014-2. Accessions – Definition and Continuation of Security Interest
cards.front: Accessions – Definition and Continuation of Security Interest
cards.backPlain: 1. Definition of Accessions 1.1 Accessions are collateral that does not lose its identity when physically united with other goods. 1.2 The item remains separately identifiable even though it is attached to or installed in a larger whole. 1.3 Example: A hard drive serving as collateral does not lose its identity when installed in a laptop. 2. Continuation of Security Interest in Accessions 2.1 A security interest can be created in an item of collateral even if it will later become physically united with other goods. 2.2 When collateral becomes an accession, an existing security interest in that item continues in the accession. 2.3 The secured party’s interest follows the item into the larger product and remains attached to that identifiable component.
cards.frontPrompt: What is an accession under Article 9, and what happens to a security interest when the collateral becomes an accession to other goods?
cards.cloze: 1. {{c1::Definition of Accessions}} 1.1 Accessions are {{c2::collateral that does not lose its identity when physically united with other goods}}. 1.2 The item remains {{c3::separately identifiable}} even though it is attached to a larger whole. 1.3 Example: A {{c4::hard drive}} used as collateral does not lose its identity when installed in a {{c5::laptop}}. 2. {{c6::Continuation of Security Interest in Accessions}} 2.1 A security interest can be created in collateral even if it will later become {{c7::physically united with other goods}}. 2.2 When collateral becomes an accession, the existing {{c8::security interest continues}} in the accession. 2.3 The secured party’s interest {{c9::follows the item into the larger product}} and remains attached to that {{c10::identifiable component}}.
cards.easyContent: Accessions are items that keep their separate identity when attached to other goods, like a hard drive in a laptop. A security interest in the item continues even after it becomes part of the larger whole.
cards.mediumContent: An accession is collateral that, when physically united with other goods, does not lose its separate identity—such as a hard drive installed in a laptop. An Article 9 security interest can be taken in the item before it is attached, and when the item becomes an accession, that existing security interest continues and follows the item into the combined product as an identifiable component.
cards.hardContent: Under Article 9, accessions are goods that become physically united with other goods but retain their separate identity. For example, a hard drive remains a distinct, identifiable component after it is installed in a laptop. A secured party may obtain a security interest in the item even before it is joined with other goods. When the collateral becomes an accession, the security interest does not disappear; it continues in the accession, following the item into the larger whole and remaining attached to that identifiable component.
cards.mnemonic: Accessions: ADDED but DISTINCT, and the lien STICKS.
cards.clozeLite: An {{c1::accession}} is collateral that, when {{c2::physically united with other goods}}, {{c3::retains its separate identity}} and any {{c4::existing Article 9 security interest continues}} in that identifiable component.

cards.subject: Secured Transactions
cards.topic: Crops – Priority Over Land Interests
cards.rawHeader: Secured Transactions 014-3. Crops – Priority Over Land Interests
cards.front: Crops – Priority Over Land Interests
cards.backPlain: 1. Priority Rule for Crops 1.1 A perfected security interest in crops takes priority over an interest in the land on which the crops are planted. 1.2 This priority rule applies regardless of the relative time of filing or perfection. 2. Effect of the Rule 2.1 Even if a landowner or mortgagee records its interest in the real property before the crop lender perfects, a perfected security interest in the crops still has priority as to the crops themselves. 2.2 The land interest continues to encumber the real property, but the crop secured party has a superior claim in the crops. 3. Summary 3.1 "Crops beat dirt": Once a security interest in crops is perfected, it outranks competing interests in the underlying land as to the crops, no matter who filed first.
cards.frontPrompt: What is the Article 9 priority rule for crops when a perfected security interest in crops conflicts with an interest in the land on which the crops are grown?
cards.cloze: 1. {{c1::Priority Rule for Crops}} 1.1 A {{c2::perfected security interest in crops}} takes priority over an {{c3::interest in the land}} on which the crops are planted. 1.2 This is true {{c4::regardless of the relative time of filing or perfection}}. 2. {{c5::Effect of the Rule}} 2.1 Even if the {{c6::landowner or mortgagee}} recorded first, a {{c7::perfected crop lender}} still has priority in the {{c8::crops themselves}}. 2.2 The {{c9::land interest}} continues to encumber the {{c10::real property}}, but the crop secured party has the {{c11::superior claim in the crops}}. 3. {{c12::Summary}} 3.1 "{{c13::Crops beat dirt}}": a perfected security interest in crops {{c14::outranks competing land interests}} as to the crops, {{c15::no matter who filed first}}.
cards.easyContent: A perfected security interest in crops has priority over any interest in the land on which the crops are grown, no matter who filed or perfected first—"crops beat dirt."
cards.mediumContent: Under Article 9, a perfected security interest in crops takes priority over an interest in the land where those crops are grown, regardless of which interest was filed or perfected first. Thus, even if a mortgagee recorded its interest in the farmland long before the crop lender, once the crop lender perfects, it has a superior claim to the crops themselves, though the land interest still encumbers the underlying real property.
cards.hardContent: Article 9 provides a special priority rule for crops: a perfected security interest in the crops has priority over an interest in the real property on which the crops are growing, regardless of the order of filing or perfection. This means that a crop lender who perfects its security interest will prevail over a landowner or mortgagee with respect to the crops themselves, even if the land interest was recorded earlier. The real property interest continues to burden the land, but the perfected crop secured party enjoys a superior claim to the crops—often summarized as "crops beat dirt."
cards.mnemonic: "Crops beat dirt"—perfected crops trump land interests.
cards.clozeLite: Under Article 9, a perfected {{c1::security interest in crops}} has priority over {{c2::interests in the land}} {{c3::regardless of filing or perfection order}}—{{c4::"crops beat dirt"}}.

cards.subject: Secured Transactions
cards.topic: Buyers vs. Unperfected Secured Parties
cards.rawHeader: Secured Transactions 015-1. Buyers vs. Unperfected Secured Parties
cards.front: Buyers vs. Unperfected Secured Parties
cards.backPlain: Buyer vs. unperfected secured party Rule: A buyer of goods can take free of an unperfected security interest if certain requirements are met. Requirements: 1. Timing: The buyer buys the goods before the secured party perfects its security interest. 2. Value and delivery: The buyer gives value and receives delivery of the goods. 3. Knowledge: The buyer has no knowledge of the security interest at the time of purchase and delivery. Effect: When these elements are met, the buyer’s interest in the goods has priority over the unperfected secured party, and the buyer takes the goods free of that security interest.
cards.frontPrompt: When does a buyer of goods take free of an unperfected secured party’s interest?
cards.cloze: A buyer of goods can take free of an {{c1::unperfected}} security interest if: 1. {{c2::Timing}}: The buyer buys the goods {{c3::before the secured party perfects}} its security interest. 2. {{c4::Value and delivery}}: The buyer {{c5::gives value}} and {{c6::receives delivery}} of the goods. 3. {{c7::Knowledge}}: The buyer has {{c8::no knowledge of the security interest}} at the time of purchase and delivery. If these elements are satisfied, the buyer’s interest {{c9::has priority}} and the buyer {{c10::takes free of}} the unperfected security interest.
cards.easyContent: A buyer beats an unperfected secured party if the buyer buys before perfection, gives value, receives delivery, and doesn’t know about the security interest.
cards.mediumContent: A buyer takes free of an unperfected security interest if the buyer (1) buys before the collateral is perfected, (2) gives value, (3) receives delivery of the goods, and (4) has no knowledge of the security interest. Meeting all four elements gives the buyer priority over the unperfected secured party.
cards.hardContent: Against an unperfected secured party, a qualifying buyer of goods can take free of the security interest. The buyer must (1) purchase the goods before the secured party perfects its interest in the collateral; (2) give value; (3) receive delivery of the goods; and (4) lack knowledge of the security interest at the time of purchase and delivery. If all these conditions are satisfied, the buyer’s rights in the goods prevail over the unperfected secured party’s rights, and the buyer takes the goods free of that security interest.
cards.mnemonic: BVDK: Buy before perfection, Value, Delivery, no Knowledge.
cards.clozeLite: A buyer takes free of an {{c1::unperfected security interest}} by {{c2::buying before perfection}}, {{c3::giving value}}, {{c4::receiving delivery}}, and {{c5::having no knowledge}}.

cards.subject: Secured Transactions
cards.topic: BIOCs vs. Perfected Secured Parties
cards.rawHeader: Secured Transactions 015-2. BIOCs vs. Perfected Secured Parties
cards.front: BIOCs vs. Perfected Secured Parties
cards.backPlain: Buyer vs. perfected secured party — BIOC exception General rule: A perfected security interest has priority over a buyer of the collateral. Exception — Buyer in the ordinary course of business (BIOC): A BIOC takes free of a nonpossessory perfected security interest in the goods if: 1. Knowledge of violation: The buyer does not know that the sale violates the terms of the seller’s security agreement. 2. BIOC status: The buyer is a "buyer in the ordinary course of business," meaning: a. The buyer purchases in the ordinary course of business; b. From a seller who is in the business of selling goods of that kind. 3. Nonpossessory interest: The secured party’s perfected security interest is nonpossessory (the debtor, not the secured party, has possession of the goods). Effect: A qualifying BIOC takes the goods free of the nonpossessory perfected security interest, even though the interest was perfected before the sale.
cards.frontPrompt: What is the general rule for buyers versus perfected secured parties, and how does the BIOC exception allow a buyer to take free of a perfected security interest?
cards.cloze: General rule: A {{c1::perfected}} security interest usually {{c2::prevails over a buyer}} of the collateral. {{c3::BIOC exception}}: A {{c4::buyer in the ordinary course of business (BIOC)}} takes free of a {{c5::nonpossessory perfected}} security interest if: 1. The buyer has {{c6::no knowledge that the sale violates}} the terms of the seller’s security agreement; and 2. The buyer is a {{c7::BIOC}}, meaning the buyer {{c8::purchases in the ordinary course of business}} from a {{c9::seller who is in the business of selling goods of that kind}}. If these conditions are met, the BIOC {{c10::takes free of}} the nonpossessory perfected security interest.
cards.easyContent: Normally, a perfected secured party beats a buyer. But a buyer in the ordinary course of business (BIOC) without knowledge that the sale violates the security agreement takes free of a nonpossessory perfected security interest when buying from a seller in the business of selling that kind of goods.
cards.mediumContent: As a default, a perfected security interest has priority over a buyer. However, a buyer in the ordinary course of business (BIOC) takes free of a nonpossessory perfected security interest if the buyer (1) has no knowledge that the sale violates the terms of the seller’s security agreement, and (2) buys in the ordinary course from a seller in the business of selling that kind of goods.
cards.hardContent: Against a perfected secured party, the general rule is that the perfected security interest prevails over a buyer of the collateral. An important exception protects buyers in the ordinary course of business (BIOCs). A BIOC takes free of a nonpossessory perfected security interest if the buyer (1) lacks knowledge that the sale violates the seller’s security agreement, and (2) qualifies as a BIOC by purchasing in the ordinary course of business from a seller who is in the business of selling goods of that kind. When these requirements are met, the BIOC’s rights in the goods trump the nonpossessory perfected security interest, even if it was perfected before the sale.
cards.mnemonic: BIOC wins: Buyer In Ordinary Course, no violation knowledge, seller of that Kind.
cards.clozeLite: A {{c1::perfected security interest}} normally beats a buyer, but a {{c2::BIOC}} without {{c3::knowledge the sale violates the security agreement}} who buys {{c4::in the ordinary course from a seller of that kind of goods}} takes free of a {{c5::nonpossessory perfected security interest}}.

cards.subject: Secured Transactions
cards.topic: PMSI in Consumer Goods — Garage Sale Rule
cards.rawHeader: Secured Transactions 015-3. PMSI in Consumer Goods — Garage Sale Rule
cards.front: PMSI in Consumer Goods — Garage Sale Rule
cards.backPlain: PMSI in consumer goods — "garage sale" rule Rule: When consumer goods subject to a purchase-money security interest (PMSI) are sold from one consumer to another, the second consumer buyer can take free of the PMSI if certain requirements are met. Requirements for the second consumer buyer to take free: 1. No knowledge: The buyer purchases without knowledge of the security interest. 2. For value: The buyer purchases the goods for value. 3. Before filing: The buyer purchases before a financing statement covering the goods has been filed. Effect: If these conditions are satisfied, the second consumer buyer takes the consumer goods free of the PMSI, even though the PMSI originally attached to the goods in the first consumer’s hands.
cards.frontPrompt: Under the PMSI in consumer goods "garage sale" rule, when does a second consumer buyer take free of the security interest?
cards.cloze: Under the {{c1::PMSI in consumer goods}} "{{c2::garage sale}}" rule, a second consumer buyer of consumer goods takes free of the PMSI if the buyer: 1. Buys {{c3::without knowledge of the security interest}}; 2. Buys {{c4::for value}}; and 3. Buys {{c5::before a financing statement covering the goods has been filed}}. When these elements are met, the second consumer buyer {{c6::takes free of}} the PMSI in the consumer goods.
cards.easyContent: In a consumer-to-consumer "garage sale" of PMSI consumer goods, the second consumer buyer takes free of the PMSI if he buys without knowledge of the interest, for value, and before any financing statement is filed.
cards.mediumContent: The "garage sale" rule applies when consumer goods subject to a PMSI are sold from one consumer to another. A second consumer buyer takes free of the PMSI if he purchases (1) without knowledge of the security interest, (2) for value, and (3) before a financing statement covering the goods has been filed.
cards.hardContent: For PMSIs in consumer goods, the "garage sale" rule protects later consumer buyers. When consumer goods subject to a PMSI are sold from one consumer to another, the second consumer buyer takes free of the PMSI if he (1) buys without knowledge of the security interest, (2) pays value, and (3) purchases before the secured party files a financing statement covering the goods. If these criteria are satisfied, the second consumer buyer’s interest in the goods prevails, and he takes the goods free of the PMSI, despite its prior attachment.
cards.mnemonic: Garage sale NFB: No knowledge, For value, Before filing.
cards.clozeLite: Under the {{c1::"garage sale" rule}}, a second consumer buyer takes free of a PMSI if he buys {{c2::without knowledge}}, {{c3::for value}}, and {{c4::before any financing statement is filed}}.

cards.subject: Secured Transactions
cards.topic: Post Default Disposition – Commercial Reasonableness, Notice, and Effect of Sale
cards.rawHeader: Secured Transactions 018-1. Post Default Disposition – Commercial Reasonableness, Notice, and Effect of Sale
cards.front: Post Default Disposition – Commercial Reasonableness, Notice, and Effect of Sale
cards.frontPrompt: After a debtor defaults under Article 9, what may a secured party do with the collateral, what notice is required, and what is the effect of a proper sale?
cards.backPlain: 1. Secured party’s right to dispose of collateral - Upon default, a secured party may dispose of collateral by sale, lease, or other disposition. - Any disposition must be conducted in a commercially reasonable manner. 2. Notice requirement - The secured party must give the debtor notice of the intended disposition. - The notice must be in an authenticated record. - It must be sent within a reasonable time before the sale or other disposition. 3. Effect of a proper sale - The sale discharges the security interest under which the sale is being made. - It also discharges any subordinate security interests and liens. - The purchaser generally takes the debtor’s rights in the collateral (subject to any senior interests that are not discharged).
cards.cloze: 1. Secured party’s right to dispose of collateral - Upon {{c1::default}}, a {{c2::secured party}} may {{c3::dispose of collateral}} by sale, lease, or other disposition. - Any disposition must be conducted in a {{c4::commercially reasonable}} manner. 2. {{c5::Notice requirement}} - The secured party must give the {{c6::debtor}} notice of the intended disposition. - The notice must be in an {{c7::authenticated record}}. - It must be sent within a {{c8::reasonable time}} before the sale or other disposition. 3. {{c9::Effect of a proper sale}} - The sale {{c10::discharges the security interest}} under which the sale is being made. - It also discharges any {{c11::subordinate security interests and liens}}. - The purchaser generally takes the {{c12::debtor’s rights in the collateral}} (subject to any senior interests).
cards.easyContent: After default, a secured party can sell, lease, or otherwise dispose of collateral if the disposition is commercially reasonable and preceded by reasonable authenticated notice to the debtor. A proper sale cuts off the foreclosing and subordinate security interests and gives the buyer the debtor’s rights in the collateral.
cards.mediumContent: Upon default, a secured party may dispose of collateral by sale, lease, or other disposition, but must do so in a commercially reasonable manner. Before the sale, the secured party must send the debtor an authenticated notice within a reasonable time. A proper sale discharges the security interest under which the sale is made and all subordinate security interests and liens, and the purchaser generally acquires the debtor’s rights in the collateral, subject to any senior interests.
cards.hardContent: Under Article 9, a secured party’s post-default remedy includes the right to dispose of the collateral by sale, lease, or any other method. The disposition must be commercially reasonable as to method, manner, time, place, and terms. Before disposing, the secured party must send the debtor an authenticated notice of disposition within a reasonable time before the sale or other disposition. A commercially reasonable disposition with proper notice discharges the security interest being foreclosed and any subordinate security interests and liens, and the purchaser takes the debtor’s rights in the collateral, leaving any senior interests in place.
cards.mnemonic: CRaN: Commercially Reasonable, Authenticated Notice, effect on interests, buyer’s Rights.
cards.clozeLite: After default, a secured party may {{c1::dispose of collateral by sale, lease, or other disposition}} if {{c2::commercially reasonable}} and {{c3::preceded by reasonable authenticated notice to the debtor}}; a proper sale {{c4::discharges the foreclosing and subordinate interests and gives the buyer the debtor’s rights}}.

cards.subject: Secured Transactions
cards.topic: Post Default Disposition – Surplus, Deficiency, and Collateral-Type Exception
cards.rawHeader: Secured Transactions 018-2. Post Default Disposition – Surplus, Deficiency, and Collateral-Type Exception
cards.front: Post Default Disposition – Surplus, Deficiency, and Exception
cards.frontPrompt: After a post-default disposition of collateral under Article 9, how are surplus and deficiency handled, and what is the key exception based on collateral type?
cards.backPlain: 1. Surplus and deficiency – General rule 1.1 Surplus - If the proceeds from the disposition of collateral exceed the remaining secured obligation: - The secured party must pay any surplus to the debtor. 1.2 Deficiency - If the proceeds from the disposition are less than the remaining secured obligation: - The debtor remains liable for the deficiency (the unpaid balance). 2. Exception for certain collateral types - When the underlying transaction involves collateral consisting of: - Accounts, - Chattel paper, - Payment intangibles, or - Promissory notes, - Neither party is liable for a surplus or a deficiency after disposition. - The secured party keeps all proceeds without owing surplus. - The debtor is not liable for any shortfall.
cards.cloze: 1. {{c1::Surplus and deficiency – General rule}} 1.1 {{c2::Surplus}} - If the proceeds from the disposition of collateral {{c3::exceed}} the remaining secured obligation: - The secured party must pay any {{c4::surplus}} to the debtor. 1.2 {{c5::Deficiency}} - If the proceeds from the disposition are {{c6::less than}} the remaining secured obligation: - The debtor remains liable for the {{c7::deficiency}} (the unpaid balance). 2. {{c8::Exception for certain collateral types}} - When the underlying transaction involves collateral consisting of: - {{c9::Accounts}}, - {{c10::Chattel paper}}, - {{c11::Payment intangibles}}, or - {{c12::Promissory notes}}, - {{c13::Neither party is liable}} for a surplus or a deficiency after disposition. - The secured party {{c14::keeps all proceeds}} without owing surplus. - The debtor is {{c15::not liable for any shortfall}}.
cards.easyContent: If a collateral sale brings in more than the debt, the surplus goes to the debtor; if it brings in less, the debtor owes the deficiency. But for accounts, chattel paper, payment intangibles, and promissory notes, there is no surplus or deficiency liability—neither side owes the other anything extra or missing.
cards.mediumContent: After a post-default disposition, if proceeds exceed the secured obligation, the secured party must remit the surplus to the debtor, and if proceeds are less, the debtor is liable for the deficiency. However, when the collateral consists of accounts, chattel paper, payment intangibles, or promissory notes, Article 9 provides that neither party is liable for any surplus or deficiency: the secured party keeps whatever is collected, and the debtor is not on the hook for any shortfall.
cards.hardContent: Article 9’s default rule is that the economic risk of a post-default disposition is shared: if the sale proceeds exceed the secured obligation, the secured party must pay the surplus to the debtor; if the proceeds are insufficient, the debtor remains liable for the resulting deficiency. An important carve-out applies when the secured obligation is secured by accounts, chattel paper, payment intangibles, or promissory notes. In such transactions, the secured party is neither required to remit any surplus nor entitled to a deficiency judgment—neither party has surplus-or-deficiency liability after disposition, regardless of the amount collected relative to the debt.
cards.mnemonic: Surplus to debtor, deficiency debtor owes—except ACPP collateral.
cards.clozeLite: After disposition, {{c1::surplus}} goes to {{c2::debtor}}, {{c3::deficiency}} is owed by {{c4::debtor}}, except for {{c5::accounts, chattel paper, payment intangibles, or promissory notes}}.

cards.subject: Secured Transactions
cards.topic: Post Default – Debtor’s Right to Redeem Collateral
cards.rawHeader: Secured Transactions 018-3. Post Default – Debtor’s Right to Redeem Collateral
cards.front: Post Default – Debtor’s Right to Redeem Collateral
cards.frontPrompt: Under Article 9, what is the debtor’s (or another secured party’s) right to redeem collateral after default, and when does it terminate?
cards.backPlain: 1. Who may redeem - The following parties have a right to redeem collateral after default: - The debtor; and - Any other secured party or lienholder in the collateral. 2. When redemption is available - The right to redeem exists: - Until the secured party has disposed of the collateral by sale or other disposition; or - Until the secured party has discharged the debt by retaining the collateral (strict foreclosure). 3. How to redeem – Amount required - To redeem, the redeeming party must: - Tender all remaining obligations secured by the collateral (i.e., pay the entire unpaid secured debt); and - Pay reasonable expenses incurred by the secured party in repossessing and holding the collateral (e.g., repossession and storage costs).
cards.cloze: 1. Who may redeem - The following parties have a right to {{c1::redeem}} collateral after default: - The {{c2::debtor}}; and - Any other {{c3::secured party or lienholder}} in the collateral. 2. When redemption is available - The right to redeem exists: - Until the secured party has {{c4::disposed of the collateral}} by sale or other disposition; or - Until the secured party has {{c5::discharged the debt by retaining the collateral}} ({{c6::strict foreclosure}}). 3. How to redeem – Amount required - To redeem, the redeeming party must: - Tender {{c7::all remaining obligations secured by the collateral}} (pay the full unpaid secured debt); and - Pay {{c8::reasonable expenses}} incurred by the secured party in {{c9::repossessing and holding}} the collateral (e.g., repossession and storage costs).
cards.easyContent: After default, the debtor and other secured parties can redeem the collateral until it is sold or the debt is satisfied by the secured party keeping the collateral. To redeem, they must pay the full remaining secured debt plus the secured party’s reasonable repossession and holding expenses.
cards.mediumContent: Article 9 gives the debtor and other secured parties or lienholders a right to redeem collateral after default. This right lasts only until the collateral is disposed of in a sale or other disposition, or the obligation is discharged by the secured party’s retention of the collateral in strict foreclosure. To exercise redemption, the redeeming party must tender the full amount of the unpaid secured obligation plus the reasonable expenses incurred by the secured party in repossessing and holding the collateral.
cards.hardContent: The Article 9 redemption right allows the debtor and other secured claimants to recover collateral after default by fully satisfying the secured obligation and associated expenses. Redemption is available only up to the earlier of: (i) the secured party’s disposition of the collateral, or (ii) the secured party’s discharge of the debt by retaining the collateral in strict foreclosure. To redeem, the redeeming party must tender the entire unpaid balance of the secured obligation together with reasonable expenses incurred by the secured party in repossession, storage, and related collection efforts. Partial payment is insufficient; redemption requires full cure of the default and associated costs.
cards.mnemonic: REDEEM: Return by Entire Debt + Expenses before Market (sale) or keeping.
cards.clozeLite: Article 9 gives a right to {{c1::redeem collateral after default}} by {{c2::tendering the full unpaid secured obligation plus reasonable expenses}} until {{c3::sale or strict foreclosure}}.
