cards.topic: Strict Foreclosure – Definition & Basic Mechanics
cards.rawHeader: Secured Transactions 019. Strict Foreclosure – Definition & Basic Mechanics
cards.front: Strict Foreclosure – Definition & Basic Mechanics
cards.frontPrompt: What is strict foreclosure under Article 9 and, in general terms, how does it operate as a default remedy?
cards.backPlain: 1. Definition and nature of strict foreclosure 1.1 Strict foreclosure is an Article 9 default remedy. 1.2 Upon default, the secured party may keep the collateral instead of selling it. 1.3 The collateral is retained in full or partial satisfaction of the secured debt. 2. Effect of strict foreclosure 2.1 If strict foreclosure is completed, the secured party takes the collateral in satisfaction of the debt to the extent agreed (full or partial). 2.2 Strict foreclosure is an alternative to a disposition (sale) of the collateral; if strict foreclosure is not permitted (e.g., due to objection), the secured party must dispose of the collateral by sale to realize on the security interest. 3. Relationship to other Article 9 remedies 3.1 Strict foreclosure is one of several post‑default remedies, alongside disposition of collateral and collection on accounts. 3.2 Choice of strict foreclosure versus sale affects whether there can be a deficiency or surplus; in strict foreclosure, the debt is satisfied to the extent of the collateral retained, and no sale proceeds are generated.
cards.cloze: 1. {{c1::Strict foreclosure}} is an {{c2::Article 9 default remedy}} in which, upon {{c3::default}}, the {{c4::secured party}} may {{c5::keep the collateral}} instead of selling it. 1.3 The collateral is retained in {{c6::full or partial satisfaction}} of the secured debt. 2.2 Strict foreclosure is an {{c7::alternative to a disposition (sale)}} of the collateral; if strict foreclosure is not permitted, the secured party must {{c8::dispose of the collateral by sale}} to realize on the security interest.
cards.easyContent: Strict foreclosure is an Article 9 remedy where, after default, the secured party keeps the collateral instead of selling it, in full or partial satisfaction of the debt.
cards.mediumContent: Strict foreclosure is an Article 9 default remedy that allows a secured party, after default, to retain the collateral in full or partial satisfaction of the debt rather than selling it. It is an alternative to a disposition by sale, and if strict foreclosure is not allowed, the secured party must instead dispose of the collateral to realize on the security interest.
cards.hardContent: Strict foreclosure is an Article 9 remedy available after default under which the secured party retains the collateral instead of disposing of it, in either full or partial satisfaction of the secured obligation. By choosing strict foreclosure, the creditor realizes on the collateral by taking it in satisfaction of the debt to the extent agreed, rather than by selling it and applying sale proceeds. If strict foreclosure is not available—for example, due to a timely objection—the secured party must instead pursue disposition by sale or other Article 9 remedies to enforce its security interest.
cards.mnemonic: "Keep, not sell" after default.
cards.clozeLite: Under Article 9, {{c1::strict foreclosure}} lets a secured party, after {{c2::default}}, {{c3::keep the collateral}} in {{c4::full or partial satisfaction}} of the debt instead of {{c5::selling it}}.

cards.subject: Secured Transactions
cards.topic: Strict Foreclosure – Debtor Consent, Notice & Objection
cards.rawHeader: Secured Transactions 019. Strict Foreclosure – Debtor Consent, Notice & Objection
cards.front: Strict Foreclosure – Consent, Notice & Objection Rules
cards.frontPrompt: What debtor consent and notice are required for strict foreclosure under Article 9, to whom must notice be sent, and what is the effect of a timely objection?
cards.backPlain: 1. Debtor consent requirement 1.1 The debtor must consent to strict foreclosure. 1.2 Debtor consent can be shown in one of two ways: 1.2.1 The debtor agrees to strict foreclosure in an authenticated record; or 1.2.2 The debtor fails to object within 20 days after the secured party sends notice of the proposed strict foreclosure. 2. Notice of intent to keep collateral 2.1 The secured party must send an authenticated notice stating that the collateral is being kept in satisfaction of the debt. 2.2 The notice must be sent to: 2.2.1 The debtor; and 2.2.2 Any other secured party who: 2.2.2.1 Has provided notice of a claim to the collateral; and 2.2.2.2 Has perfected a security interest in the collateral by filing a financing statement or by making a notation on a certificate of title. 3. Objection and its effect 3.1 No timely objection: If no notified party objects within 20 days after the notice is sent, the strict foreclosure may proceed. 3.2 Timely objection: If any notified party objects within 20 days, the secured party may not complete strict foreclosure and instead must dispose of the collateral by sale.
cards.cloze: 1. {{c1::Debtor consent}} requirement 1.2 Debtor consent can be shown in one of two ways: 1.2.1 The debtor agrees to strict foreclosure in an {{c2::authenticated record}}; or 1.2.2 The debtor {{c3::fails to object within 20 days}} after the secured party sends notice of the proposed strict foreclosure. 2. {{c4::Notice of intent to keep collateral}} 2.1 The secured party must send an {{c5::authenticated notice}} stating that the collateral is being kept in {{c6::satisfaction of the debt}}. 2.2 The notice must be sent to the {{c7::debtor}} and to any other {{c8::secured party}} who has provided {{c9::notice of a claim to the collateral}} and has {{c10::perfected}} a security interest in the collateral by filing or notation on a {{c11::certificate of title}}. 3. {{c12::Objection and its effect}} 3.1 If no notified party objects within {{c13::20 days}} after the notice is sent, the strict foreclosure may proceed. 3.2 If any notified party objects within 20 days, the secured party must {{c14::dispose of the collateral by sale}} instead of keeping it.
cards.easyContent: Strict foreclosure requires debtor consent, which can be given in an authenticated record or by failing to object within 20 days after notice. The secured party must send authenticated notice to the debtor and certain other secured parties, and any timely objection within 20 days blocks strict foreclosure and forces a sale.
cards.mediumContent: To use strict foreclosure, the secured party must obtain debtor consent, either through an authenticated agreement to strict foreclosure or by the debtor’s failure to object within 20 days after receiving notice. The secured party must send an authenticated notice stating that it will keep the collateral in satisfaction of the debt to the debtor and to other secured parties who have claimed an interest and perfected by filing or notation on a certificate of title. If no notified party objects within 20 days, strict foreclosure may proceed; if any notified party objects within that period, the secured party must instead dispose of the collateral by sale.
cards.hardContent: Article 9 conditions strict foreclosure on consent and notice/objection procedures. The debtor must consent either by agreeing to strict foreclosure in an authenticated record or by failing to object within 20 days after the secured party sends an authenticated notice of its intent to retain the collateral in satisfaction of the debt. The secured party must send that authenticated notice to the debtor and to any other secured party that has given notice of a claim to the collateral and has perfected its security interest by filing a financing statement or by notation on a certificate of title. If no notified party objects within 20 days after the notice is sent, the strict foreclosure may be completed. However, if any notified party objects within that 20‑day window, strict foreclosure is barred and the secured party must instead dispose of the collateral by sale to enforce its security interest.
cards.mnemonic: Consent + 20 days silence OK; any objection = sell.
cards.clozeLite: Strict foreclosure needs {{c1::debtor consent}} and {{c2::authenticated notice}}; {{c3::20 days to object}} and {{c4::any timely objection blocks strict foreclosure}}.

cards.topic: Strict Foreclosure – Special Consumer Rules
cards.rawHeader: Secured Transactions 019. Strict Foreclosure – Special Consumer Rules
cards.front: Strict Foreclosure – Consumer-Transaction Limitations
cards.frontPrompt: What special limitations apply to strict foreclosure in consumer transactions, including the rules on partial satisfaction with a deficiency and the 60%/90-day sale rule?
cards.backPlain: 1. Consumer transactions – no partial satisfaction plus deficiency 1.1 In consumer transactions, a secured party may not keep collateral in partial satisfaction of the debt and then seek a deficiency judgment for the remaining unpaid balance. 1.2 This rule prevents a secured party from both retaining valuable consumer collateral and also pursuing the debtor for the deficiency. 2. Consumer goods with high payment threshold – 60%/90‑day rule 2.1 Where the debtor has paid at least 60% of a purchase‑money security interest (PMSI) or other loan in consumer goods, the secured party is generally not allowed to keep the collateral in strict foreclosure. 2.2 Instead, the secured party must sell the collateral within 90 days after repossession. 2.3 The debtor may waive the right to require a sale, allowing the secured party to keep the collateral, but such waiver must comply with applicable Article 9 requirements. 3. Policy 3.1 These consumer‑specific limits are designed to protect consumer debtors from overreaching by secured creditors who might otherwise retain high‑value goods while still collecting a deficiency.
cards.cloze: 1. {{c1::Consumer transactions}} – no partial satisfaction plus deficiency 1.1 In consumer transactions, a secured party may not keep collateral in {{c2::partial satisfaction}} of the debt and then seek a {{c3::deficiency judgment}} for the remaining unpaid balance. 2. {{c4::Consumer goods with high payment threshold}} – {{c5::60%/90‑day rule}} 2.1 Where the debtor has paid at least {{c6::60%}} of a PMSI or other loan in consumer goods, the secured party must {{c7::sell the collateral within 90 days}} after repossession, unless the debtor {{c8::waives}} the right to require a sale. 3. Policy 3.1 These rules protect {{c9::consumer debtors}} from secured creditors retaining valuable consumer goods while still pursuing a {{c10::deficiency}}.
cards.easyContent: In consumer transactions, a secured party cannot both keep consumer collateral in partial satisfaction of the debt and still seek a deficiency. Also, if the debtor has paid at least 60% of a loan in consumer goods, the creditor must sell the collateral within 90 days of repossession unless the debtor waives that right.
cards.mediumContent: Article 9 imposes extra limits on strict foreclosure in consumer cases. A secured party in a consumer transaction may not retain the collateral in partial satisfaction of the debt and then pursue the consumer for a deficiency. In addition, if the debtor has paid at least 60% of a PMSI or other loan in consumer goods, the secured party generally must sell the collateral within 90 days after repossession rather than keep it, unless the debtor validly waives the right to require a sale.
cards.hardContent: Consumer‑protection provisions limit the use of strict foreclosure in consumer transactions. A secured party dealing with a consumer debtor may not retain consumer collateral in partial satisfaction of the debt and then sue for a deficiency judgment on the remainder; the creditor must choose between keeping the collateral in full satisfaction or disposing of it and pursuing any deficiency under Article 9’s usual rules. Furthermore, when the collateral consists of consumer goods and the debtor has already paid at least 60% of a PMSI or other loan in those goods, the secured party is required to sell the collateral within 90 days of repossession rather than keep it, unless the consumer debtor validly waives the right to require a sale. These rules are designed to prevent overreaching by secured creditors against consumer debtors.
cards.mnemonic: Consumer shield: no keep-plus-deficiency; 60% paid means sell in 90 days.
cards.clozeLite: In consumer cases, a secured party cannot {{c1::retain collateral in partial satisfaction and still seek a deficiency}} and, if {{c2::60% of a consumer-goods loan is paid}}, must {{c3::sell the collateral within 90 days of repossession unless the debtor waives}}.

cards.topic: Interstate Movement – General Temporary Perfection & Debtor Relocation
cards.rawHeader: Secured Transactions 022-1. Interstate Movement – General Temporary Perfection & Debtor Relocation
cards.front: Interstate Movement – General Temporary Perfection & Debtor Relocation
cards.backPlain: 1. General temporary perfection when debtor or collateral moves 1.1 Issues arise when the debtor or the collateral moves from one state to another. 1.2 A security interest that was perfected in the original state generally remains temporarily perfected after the move. 1.3 This temporary perfection gives the secured party time to perfect in the new state. 1.4 If the secured party fails to perfect in the new state within the applicable period, the security interest becomes unperfected and loses its original priority date. 2. Debtor relocation – four‑month rule 2.1 If the debtor relocates to a new state, a security interest perfected under the law of the original state remains perfected for four months after the debtor’s relocation. 2.2 To remain continuously perfected and keep the original priority date, the secured party must perfect under the law of the new jurisdiction before the four‑month period expires.
cards.frontPrompt: What happens to a perfected security interest when the debtor or collateral moves to another state, and what is the four‑month rule for debtor relocation?
cards.cloze: 1. General temporary perfection when debtor or collateral moves 1.1 Issues arise when the {{c1::debtor or the collateral moves from one state to another}}. 1.2 A security interest perfected in the original state generally remains {{c2::temporarily perfected}} after the move. 1.3 This temporary perfection gives the secured party time to {{c3::perfect in the new state}}. 1.4 If the secured party fails to perfect in the new state within the applicable period, the security interest becomes {{c4::unperfected}} and loses its {{c5::original priority date}}. 2. Debtor relocation – four‑month rule 2.1 If the debtor relocates to a new state, a security interest perfected under the law of the original state remains perfected for {{c6::four months}} after the debtor’s relocation. 2.2 To remain continuously perfected and keep the original priority date, the secured party must perfect under the law of the new jurisdiction {{c7::before the four‑month period expires}}.
cards.easyContent: When the debtor or collateral moves to another state, a perfected security interest usually remains temporarily perfected. If the debtor moves, perfection in the old state continues for four months, during which the secured party must perfect in the new state to keep continuous perfection and priority.
cards.mediumContent: Article 9 gives temporary perfection when the debtor or collateral crosses state lines. A security interest perfected in the original state continues to be perfected for a limited time, giving the secured party a chance to reperfect under the new state’s law. If the debtor relocates, the prior perfection continues for four months from the date of relocation. To maintain continuous perfection and preserve the original priority date, the secured party must perfect in the new debtor’s state before that four‑month period ends. If the secured party fails to do so, the security interest becomes unperfected and loses its original priority date.
cards.hardContent: Article 9’s interstate rules begin with a general principle: when either the debtor or the collateral moves to another state, a security interest that was perfected under the law of the original state remains temporarily perfected, giving the secured party time to adjust to the new jurisdiction. Specifically, the interest stays perfected for a limited period; if the secured party does not perfect in the new state within that time, the security interest becomes unperfected and loses its original priority date as against competing claimants. In the particular case of debtor relocation, a security interest perfected under the original state’s law remains perfected for four months after the debtor moves. To maintain continuous perfection and preserve the original priority date, the secured party must file or otherwise perfect under the law of the new debtor’s state before that four‑month period expires; failure to do so results in loss of perfection and priority.
cards.mnemonic: "4 FOR MOVE" – four months to reperfect after debtor moves.
cards.clozeLite: If a {{c1::debtor relocates}} to another state, prior perfection continues for {{c2::four months}}; the secured party must {{c3::reperfect in the new state}} within that time to keep {{c4::continuous perfection and priority}}.

cards.topic: Interstate Movement – Possessory Interests & Certificate‑of‑Title Vehicles
cards.rawHeader: Secured Transactions 022-2. Interstate Movement – Possessory Interests & Certificate‑of‑Title Vehicles
cards.front: Interstate Movement – Possessory Interests & Certificate‑of‑Title Vehicles
cards.backPlain: 1. Possessory security interest and movement of collateral 1.1 If collateral in one state is perfected by a possessory security interest in that state and the collateral is moved to a new state, the security interest remains perfected as long as it would be perfected by possession under the laws of the new state. 2. Cars/vehicles and certificate of title 2.1 If a vehicle covered by a certificate of title is moved from one state to another and the new state issues a new certificate of title, the original perfected security interest lasts as long as it would have lasted had the new title not been issued.
cards.frontPrompt: How does Article 9 treat perfection when collateral perfected by possession or a certificate‑of‑title vehicle is moved to another state?
cards.cloze: 1. Possessory security interest and movement of collateral 1.1 If collateral in one state is perfected by a {{c1::possessory security interest}} in that state and the collateral is moved to a new state, the security interest remains perfected as long as it would be perfected by {{c2::possession}} under the laws of the {{c3::new state}}. 2. Cars/vehicles and certificate of title 2.1 If a vehicle covered by a {{c4::certificate of title}} is moved from one state to another and the new state issues a new certificate of title, the original perfected security interest lasts as long as it would have lasted {{c5::had the new title not been issued}}.
cards.easyContent: If collateral perfected by possession is moved to another state, perfection continues as long as possession would perfect under the new state’s law. For vehicles covered by a certificate of title that move and get a new title, the original secured party’s perfection continues for as long as it would have if the new title had never been issued.
cards.mediumContent: Article 9 preserves perfection when collateral perfected by possession or certificate‑of‑title goods move across state lines. For collateral perfected by a possessory security interest, moving the collateral to a new state does not automatically destroy perfection; the security interest remains perfected as long as possession of the collateral would constitute perfection under the law of the new state. For vehicles or other goods covered by a certificate of title, if the goods are taken to another state and that state issues a new certificate of title, the secured party’s original perfected security interest continues for as long as it would have lasted if no new certificate of title had been issued in the new state.
cards.hardContent: When collateral perfected by possession or certificate‑of‑title goods move interstate, Article 9 supplies specific continuity rules. If collateral located in one state is perfected by a possessory security interest and is then moved to a different state, the security interest remains perfected so long as possession of the collateral would perfect the interest under the laws of the new state. Thus, the critical question is whether the new state also recognizes perfection by possession for that type of collateral. For cars, vehicles, and other certificate‑of‑title goods, when the goods are moved to another state and that state issues a new certificate of title, the original perfected security interest does not automatically lapse. Instead, it continues for as long as it would have continued had the new certificate of title not been issued, preserving the original secured party’s perfection despite the new documentation.
cards.mnemonic: Possession travels; new title doesn’t terminate old perfection.
cards.clozeLite: If collateral perfected by {{c1::possession}} moves states, perfection continues if {{c2::the new state also perfects by possession}}. For {{c3::certificate-of-title vehicles}}, a new title {{c4::does not cut off the original perfection}}.

cards.topic: Interstate Movement – New Debtor in Different State (One‑Year Rule)
cards.rawHeader: Secured Transactions 022-3. Interstate Movement – New Debtor in Different State (One‑Year Rule)
cards.front: Interstate Movement – New Debtor in Different State (One‑Year Rule)
cards.backPlain: 1. New debtor in different state 1.1 This issue arises when a new debtor located in a different state becomes bound by another person’s security agreement. 1.2 If collateral is transferred to a new debtor located in a different state, a security interest perfected under the law of the original debtor’s state remains perfected until one year after the sale or transfer of the collateral or until perfection in the original state lapses, whichever occurs first.
cards.frontPrompt: What happens to a perfected security interest when collateral is transferred to a new debtor in another state who becomes bound by the security agreement?
cards.cloze: 1. New debtor in different state 1.1 This issue arises when a {{c1::new debtor}} located in a {{c2::different state}} becomes bound by another person’s security agreement. 1.2 If collateral is transferred to a new debtor in a different state, a security interest perfected under the law of the original debtor’s state remains perfected until {{c3::one year after the sale or transfer of the collateral}} or until {{c4::perfection in the original state lapses}}, whichever occurs first.
cards.easyContent: When collateral is transferred to a new debtor in another state who becomes bound by the security agreement, the original secured party’s perfection continues for up to one year after the transfer, or until perfection in the original state would have lapsed, whichever is earlier.
cards.mediumContent: Article 9 covers the situation where a new debtor in a different state becomes bound by someone else’s security agreement and receives the collateral. A security interest that was perfected under the original debtor’s state remains perfected despite the transfer and the new debtor’s different location. However, this continued perfection is limited: it lasts until one year after the sale or transfer of the collateral to the new debtor, or until the time when perfection in the original state would have lapsed, whichever occurs first.
cards.hardContent: When a new debtor located in a different state becomes bound by another person’s security agreement and collateral is transferred to that new debtor, Article 9 provides a limited grace period to preserve the original secured party’s perfection. A security interest perfected under the law of the original debtor’s state remains perfected even though the collateral is now associated with a new debtor in another state. This continued perfection is not indefinite: it lasts until one year after the sale or transfer of the collateral to the new debtor, or until perfection in the original state would have lapsed under its own terms (e.g., failure to continue a financing statement), whichever occurs first. The secured party must perfect under the law of the new debtor’s state within that period if it wishes to maintain continuous perfection and priority beyond the grace period.
cards.mnemonic: "1 year for NEW DEBTOR" – original perfection lasts one year or until it would lapse.
cards.clozeLite: If collateral goes to a {{c1::new debtor in another state}} bound by the agreement, original perfection continues for {{c2::one year}} or until {{c3::original-state perfection lapses}}, whichever is first.
